editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: PHILIPPI was ≈øo called from Philip King of Macedonia, who much enlarged and beautified it. Afterwards it became a Roman Colony, and the chief City of that Part of Macedonia. Hither St. Paul was ≈øent by a Vi≈øion to preach; and here, not long after his Coming, he was ≈øhamefully intreated. Neverthele≈øs many were converted by him, during the ≈øhort Time of his Abode there; by who≈øe Liberality he was more a≈ø≈øi≈øted, than by any other Church of his planting. And they had now ≈øent large A≈ø≈øi≈øtance to him by Epaphroditus; by whom he returns them this Epi≈øtle.

It contains ≈øix Parts,
I. The In≈øcription, C. i. 1, 2
II. Thank≈øgiving and Prayers for them, 3‚Äî11
III. He relates his pre≈øent State and good Hope: Whence he exhorts them, 12‚Äî14
1. While he remains with them, to walk worthy of the Go≈øpel, 25‚Äî30
2. Though he ≈øhould be killed, to rejoice with him, And promi≈øes, 17, 18

2. In the mean time to ≈øend Epaphroditus, 25‚Äî30
IV. He exhorts them to rejoice, C. iii. 1‚Äî3
admonithing them, to beware of fal≈øe Teachers, and to imitate the true, 2‚Äî21
commending Concord, C. iv. 1‚Äî3
He again exhorts them to Joy and Meekne≈øs, 4‚Äî7
and to what≈øoever Things are excellent, 8‚Äî9

VI. The Conclu≈øion, 21‚Äî23

PAUL and Timotheus, ≈øervants of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, to all the ≈øaints in Chri≈øt Je≈øus who are at Philippi, with the bi≈øhops and deacons, Grace be unto you, and peace from God our Father and the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt. I thank my God upon every mention of you, Always in all my prayers making ≈øupplication for you all with joy, For your fellow≈øhip in the go≈øpel from the fir≈øt day until now: Being per≈øuaded of this very thing, that he who hath begun a good work in you, will perfect it until the day of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, As it is right for me to think this of you all, becau≈øe I have you in my heart, who were all partakers of my grace, both in my bonds, and in the defence and confirmation
of the go≈øpel. For God is my witne≈øs, how I long for you all, with the bowers of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. And this I pray, that your love may abound yet more and more, in all knowledge and in all ≈øpiritual ≈øen≈øe, That ye may try the things that are excellent, that ye may be ≈øincere and without offence unto the day of Chri≈øt, Being filled with the fruits of righteou≈øne≈øs, which are through Chri≈øt Je≈øus, to the glory and prai≈øe of God.

Now I would have you know, brethren, that the things concerning me have fallen out rather to the furtherance of the go≈øpel: So that my bonds in Chri≈øt have been made manife≈øt in the
whole palace, and to all others: And many of the brethren tru≈øting in the Lord through my bonds, are more abundantly bold to ≈øpeak the word without fear.

Some indeed preach Chri≈øt even through envy and ≈øtrife; but ≈øome through good will. The one preach Chri≈øt out of contention, not ≈øincerely, ≈øuppo≈øing to add affliction to my bonds: But the others out of love, knowing that I am ≈øet for the defence of the go≈øpel. What then? ≈øtill every way, whether in pretence or in truth, Chri≈øt is preached; and in this I rejoice, yea, and will rejoice. For I know that this ≈øhall turn to my ≈øalvation, through your prayer, and the ≈øupply of the Spirit of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: According to my earne≈øt expectation and hope, that I ≈øhall be a≈øhamed in nothing, but that with all boldne≈øs, as always, ≈øo now al≈øo, Chri≈øt ≈øhall be magnified in my body, whether by life or by death.

For to me to live is Chri≈øt, and to die is gain.
But if I am to live in the fle≈øh, this is the fruit of my labour, and what I ≈øhould chu≈øe, I know not. For I am in a ≈øtrait between two, having a de≈øire to depart and to be with Chri≈øt, which is far better. But to remain in the fle≈øh is more needful for you. And being per≈øuaded of this, I know that I ≈øhall remain and continue with you all, for your furtherance and joy of faith: That your rejoicing for me may abound through Chri≈øt Je≈øus, by my pre≈øence with you again. Only let your behaviour be worthy of the go≈øpel of Chri≈øt, that whether I come and ≈øee you, or be ab≈øent, I may hear concerning you, that ye ≈øtand fa≈øt, in one ≈øpirit, with one ≈øoul ≈øtriving together for the faith of the go≈øpel, And in nothing terrified by your adver≈øaries, which is to them an evident token of perdition, but to you of ≈øalvation. This al≈øo is of God. For to you it is given with regard to Chri≈øt, not only to believe on him, but al≈øo to ≈øuffer for him: Having the ≈øame conflict, which ye ≈øaw in me, and now
hear to be in me.

V. 1. Servants‚ÄîSt. Paul writing familiarly to the Philippians, does not ≈øtile him≈øelf and Apo≈øtle. And under the common Title of Servants, he tenderly and mode≈øtly joins with him≈øelf his Son Timotheus, who had come to Philippi not long after St. Paul had received him, Acts xvi. 3, 12. To all the Saints‚ÄîI he Apo≈øtolic Epi≈øtles were ≈øent more directly to the Churches, than to the Pa≈øtors of them; with the bi≈øhops and deacons‚ÄîThe former properly took Care of the internal State, the latter of the Externals of the Church, (1 Tim. iii. 2‚Äî8.) Although the≈øe were not wholly confined to the one, neither tho≈øe to the other. The Word Bi≈øhops here includes all the Pre≈øbyters as Philippi, as well as the Ruling Pre≈øbyters: The Names Bi≈øhop and Pre≈øbyter, or
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ der, being promi≈øcuou≈øly u≈øed in the Fir≈øt Ages.

V. 4. With joy‚ÄîAfter the Epi≈øtle to the Ephe≈øians, wherein Love reigns, follows this, wherein there is perpetual Mention of Joy. The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy. And Joy peculiarly enlivens Prayer. The Sum of the whole Epi≈øtle is, I rejoice. Rejoice ye.
V. 5. The Sen≈øe is, I thank God for your fellow≈øhip with us in all the Ble≈ø≈øings of the go≈øpel which I have done from the fir≈øt day of your receiving it until now.

V. 6. Being per≈øuaded‚ÄîThe Grounds of which Per≈øua≈øion are ≈øet down in the following Ver≈øe, that he who hath begun a good work in you, will perfect it until the day of Chri≈øt‚ÄîThat he who having ju≈øtified, hath begun to ≈øanctify you, will carry on this Work, till it i≈ø≈øue in Glory.

V. 7. As it is right for me to think this of you all‚ÄîWhy? He does not ≈øay, "Becau≈øe of at Eternal Decree;" or, Becau≈øe a Saint mu≈øt per≈øevere; but Becau≈øe I have you in my heart, who were all partakers of my grace‚ÄîThat is, Becau≈øe ye were all (for which I have you in my heart‚ÄîI bear you the mo≈øt grateful and tender Affection) partakers of my grace‚ÄîThat is, Sharers in the Afflictions, which
GOD vouch≈øafed me as a Grace or Favour, (ver. 29, 30.) both in my bonds, and when I was called forth to an≈øwer for my≈øelf, and to confirm the Go≈øpel. It is not improbable, that, after they had endured that great trial of affliction, GOD had ≈øealed them unto full Victory, of which the Apo≈øtle had a prophetic Sight.

V. 8. I long for you all with the bowels of Je≈øus Chri≈øt‚ÄîIn Paul, not Paul lives, but Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Therefore he longs for them, with the bowels, the Tenderne≈øs, not of Paul, but of Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

V. 9. And this I pray, that your love‚ÄîWhich they had already ≈øhewn, may abound yet more and more‚ÄîThe Fire which burnt in the Apo≈øtle, never ≈øays, It is enough: in knowledge and in all ≈øpiritual ≈øen≈øe‚ÄîWhich is the Ground of all ≈øpiritual Knowledge. We must be inwardly ≈øen≈øible of divine Peace, Joy, Love; otherwi≈øe we cannot know what they are.

V. 10. That ye may try‚ÄîBy that ≈øpiritual Sen≈øe the things that are excellent‚ÄîNot only good, but the very be≈øt: The ≈øuperior Excellence of which is hardly di≈øcerned, but by the adult Chri≈øtian: that ye may be inwardly ≈øincere‚ÄîHaving a ≈øingle Eye, to the very be≈øt things, and a pure Heart, and outwardly without offence‚ÄîHoly, unblamable in all Things.

V. 11. Being filled with the fruits of rightcou≈øne≈øs, which are through Je≈øus Chri≈øt, to the glory and prai≈øe of God‚ÄîHere are three properties of that Sincerity, which is acceptable to GOD. 1. It mu≈øt bear Fruits, the fruits of Righteou≈øne≈øs, all inward and outward Holine≈øs, all good Tempers, Words, and Works, and that ≈øo abundantly, that we may be filled with them: 2. The Branch and the Fruits mu≈øt derive both their Virtue and their very Being from the all-≈øupporting, all-≈øupplying Root, Je≈øus Chri≈øt: 3. As all the≈øe flow from the Grace of Chri≈øt ≈øo they mu≈øt i≈ø≈øue in the glory and prai≈øe of God.
V. 12. The things concerning me‚ÄîMy Sufferings, have fallen out rather to the furtherance than (as you feared) the Hindrance of the go≈øpel.

V. 13. My bonds in Chri≈øt‚ÄîEndured for his Sake, have been made
manife≈øt‚ÄîMuch taken Notice of, in the whole palace‚ÄîOf the Roman Emperor.
V. 14. And many‚ÄîWho were before afraid, tru≈øting in the Lord through my bonds‚ÄîWhen they ob≈øerved my Con≈øtancy, and Safety notwith≈øtanding, are more bold.

V. 15 , 16. Some indeed preach Chri≈øt out of contention‚ÄîEnvying St. Paul's Succe≈øs, and ≈øtriving to hurt him thereby; not ≈øincerely‚Äî From a real De≈øire to glorify God, but ≈øuppo≈øing‚ÄîThough they were di≈øappointed, to add more afflictions to my bonds‚ÄîBy inraging the Romans again≈øt me.

Some indeed preach Chri≈øt out of contention‚ÄîEnvying St. Paul's Succe≈øs, and ≈øtriving to hurt him thereby; not ≈øincerely‚Äî From a real De≈øire to glorify God, but ≈øuppo≈øing‚ÄîThough they were di≈øappointed, to add more afflictions to my bonds‚ÄîBy inraging the Romans again≈øt me.

V. 17. But the others out of love‚ÄîTo Chri≈øt and me; knowing‚Äî Not barely ≈øuppo≈øing, that I am ≈øet‚ÄîLiterally I lie: Yet ≈øtill going forward in his work. He remained at Rome as an Amba≈ø≈øador in a Place where he is employed on an important Emba≈ø≈øy.

div.head: II.
div.p:
If there be then any con≈øolation in Chri≈øt, if any comfort of love, if any fellow≈øhip of the Spirit, if any bowels of mercies; Fulfil ye my joy, that ye think the ≈øame thing, having the ≈øame love, being of one ≈øoul, of one mind. Do nothing through ≈øtrife or vain glory, but in lowline≈øs of mind, e≈øteem each the others better than them≈øelves. Aim not every one at his own things, but every one al≈øo at the things of others. Let this mind be in you, which was al≈øo in Chri≈øt Je≈øus, Who being in the form of God, counted it no act of robbery to be equal with God; Yet emptied him≈øelf,
taking the form of a ≈øervant, being made in the likene≈øs of men. And being found in fa≈øhion as a man, he humbled him≈øelf, becoming obedient even unto death, yea, the death of the cro≈øs. Wherefore God al≈øo hath highly exalted him, and hath given him a name which is above every name, That at the name of Je≈øus every knee might bow, of tho≈øe in heaven, and tho≈øe on earth, and tho≈øe under the earth: And every tongue might confe≈øs, that Je≈øus Chri≈øt is Lord in the glory of God the Father. Wherefore, my beloved, as you have always obeyed, not as in my pre≈øence only, but much more now in my ab≈øence, work out your own ≈øalvation
with fear and trembling. For it is God that worketh in you according to his good plea≈øure, both to will and to do. Do all things without murmurings and di≈øputings: That ye may be blamele≈øs and ≈øimple, the ≈øons of God, unrebukable, in the mid≈øt of a crooked and perver≈øe generation, among whom ye ≈øhine as lights in the world, Holding fa≈øt the word of life, that I may glory in the day of Chri≈øt, that I have not run in vain, neither laboured in vain.

Yea, and if I be offered up on the ≈øacrifice and ≈øervice of your faith, I rejoice and congratulate you all. For the ≈øame cau≈øe rejoice ye likewi≈øe, and congratulate me. Now I tru≈øt in the Lord Je≈øus, to ≈øend Timotheus to you thortly, that I al≈øo may be encouraged, when I know your ≈øtate, For I have none like-minded, who will naturally care for what concerneth you. For all ≈øeek their own, not the
things of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. But ye know the proof of him, that as a ≈øon with his father, he hath ≈øerved with me in the go≈øpel. Him therefore I hope to ≈øend, as ≈øoon as ever I know how it will go with me. But I tru≈øt in the Lord that I al≈øo my≈øelf ≈øhall come ≈øhortly. Yet I thought it nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øend to you Epaphroditus, my brother and companion in labour and fellow-≈øoldier, but your me≈ø≈øenger, and him that mini≈øtered to my need. For he longed after you all, and was full of heavine≈øs, becau≈øe ye had heard that he was ≈øick. He was indeed ≈øick nigh unto death; but God had compa≈ø≈øion on him; and not on him only, but on me likewi≈øe, left I ≈øhould have ≈øorrow upon ≈øorrow. I have ≈øent him therefore the more willingly, that ye ≈øeeing him again my rejoice, and that I al≈øo may be the le≈øs ≈øorrowful. Receive him therefore in the Lord with all gladne≈øs, and honour ≈øuch. Becau≈øe for the work of Chri≈øt he was nigh unto death, not regarding his own life, to ≈øupply your deficiency of ≈øervice toward me.

V. 1. If there be therefore any con≈øolation‚ÄîIn the Grace of Chri≈øt, if any comfort‚ÄîIn the Love of GOD, if any follow≈øhip of the Holy Gho≈øt; if any bowels of mercies‚ÄîRe≈øulting therefrom; any tender Affection towards each other.

V. 2. Think the ≈øame thing‚ÄîSeeing Chri≈øt is your common Head; having the ≈øame love‚ÄîTo GOD, your common Father: being of one ≈øoul‚ÄîAnimated with the ≈øame Affections and Tempers, as ye have all drank into one Spirit; of one mind‚ÄîTenderly rejoicing and grieving together.

V. 3. Do nothing through contention‚ÄîWhich is incon≈øi≈øtent with your thinking the ≈øame Thing, or vain-glory‚ÄîDe≈øire of Prai≈øe, which is directly oppo≈øite to the Love of GOD; but e≈øteem each the others better than them≈øelves‚Äî(For every one knows more Evil of him≈øelf than he can of another.) Which is a glorious Fruit of the Spirit, and an admirable Help to your continuing of one ≈øoul.
V. 4. Aim not every one at his own things‚ÄîOnly. If ≈øo, ye have not Bowels of Mercies.

V. 6. Who being in the e≈ø≈øential form, the incommunicable Nature of God from Eternity (as he was afterward in the form of man, real GOD, as real Man) counted it no act of robbery (that is the preci≈øe Meaning of the Words) no inva≈øion of another's Prerogative, but his own ≈øtrict and unque≈øtionable Right, to be equal with God. The Word here tran≈ølated equal, occurs in the Adjective ‚Ä¢ orm, five or ≈øix Times in the New Te≈øtament, Mat. xx. 12. Lake vi. 34. John v. 18. Acts. xi. 17. Rev. xxi. 16. In all which Places it expre≈ø≈øes not a bare Re≈øemblance, but a real and proper Equality. It here implies both the Fulne≈øs and the ≈øupreme Height of the Godhead; to which are oppo≈øed, he emptied and he humbled him≈øelf.

V. 7. Yet‚ÄîHe was ≈øo far from ten ‚Ä¢ ciou≈øly in≈øi≈øting upon, that he willingly relinqui≈øhed his Claim. He was content to f ‚Ä¢ reto the G ‚Ä¢ ries of the Creator, and to appear in the Form of a Creature: Nay, to be made in the Likene≈øs of the fallen Creatures; and not only to ≈øhare the Di≈øgrace, but to ≈øuffer the Pani≈øhment due to the meat e≈øt and v ‚Ä¢ le≈øt among them all. He emptied him≈øelf‚ÄîOf that Divine Fulne≈øs, which he received again at his Exaltation. Though he remained foul. John i. 14.) yet he appeared as if he had been empty; for he veiled his
Fulne≈øs from the Sight of Men and Angels. Yea, he not only veiled, but in ≈øome Sen≈øe renounced the Glory which he had before the World began; taking‚ÄîAnd by that very Act emptying him≈øelf, the form of a ≈øervant‚ÄîThe form, the likene≈øs, the fa≈øhion, though not exactly the ≈øame, are yet nearly related to each other. The form expre≈ø≈øes ≈øomething ab≈øolute; the likene≈øs refers to other Things of the ≈øame Kind; the fa≈øhion re≈øpects what appears to Sight and Sen≈øe; being made in the likene≈øs of men‚ÄîA real Man, like other Men. div.head: I.
div.p:
GOD, who at ≈øundry times and in divers manners ≈øpake of old to the fathers by the prophets, hath in the≈øe la≈øt days ≈øpoken to us by his Son; Whom he hath appointed heir of all things,
by whom he al≈øo made the worlds: Who, being the brightne≈øs of his glory, and the expre≈øs image of his per≈øon, and ≈øu≈øtaining all things by the word of his power, when he had by him≈øelf purged our ≈øins, ≈øat down on the right hand of the Maje≈øty on high, Being ≈øo much higher than the angels, as he hath by inheritance a more excellent name
than they. For to which of the angels did he ever ≈øay,
P≈øalm ii. 7.@ Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee? And again, 2 Sam. vii. 14.@ I will be to him a Father, and he ≈øhall be to me a Son? And again,
P≈øalm xcvii. 7.@ When he bringeth in the fir≈øt begotten into the world, he ≈øaith, And let all the angels of God wor≈øhip him. And of the angels he ≈øaith,
Ib.
‚Ä¢ iv. 4.@ Who maketh his angels ≈øpirits, and his mini≈øters a flame of fire. But unto the Son,
P≈øalm xlv. 6, 7.@ Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever; the ≈øceptre of thy kingdom is a ≈øceptre of righteou≈øne≈øs: Thou ha≈øt loved righteou≈øne≈øs and hated iniquity; therefore God, even thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladne≈øs
above thy fellows. And,
P≈øalm cii. 25, 26, &c.@ Thou, Lord, ha≈øt in the beginning laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the works of thy hands. They ≈øhall peri≈øh, but thou endure≈øt; yea, they all ≈øhall grow old as a garment; And as a mantle ≈øhalt thou change them, and they ≈øhall be changed: but thou art the ≈øame, and thy years ≈øhall not fail. But to which of the angels did he ever ≈øay,
Ib. cx. 1.@ Sit at my right hand, 'till I make thine enemies thy foot≈øtool? Are they not all mini≈øtring ≈øpirits, ≈øent forth to attend on them who ≈øhall inherit ≈øalvation?

V. 1. God, who at ≈øundry times‚ÄîThe Creation was revealed in the Time of Adam, the la≈øt Judgment in the Time of Enoch; and ≈øo at various Times and in various Degrees more explicit Knowledge was given, in divers manners‚ÄîIn Vi≈øions, in Dreams, and by Revelations of various Kinds. Both the≈øe are oppo≈øed to the One intire and perfect Revelation which he has made to us by J ‚Ä¢ ≈øus Chri≈øt. The very Number of the Prophets ≈øhewed, that they prophe≈øied only in part: of old‚ÄîThere were no Prophets for a large Tract of Time before Chri≈øt came, that the Great Prophet might be the more earne≈øtly expected; ≈øpake‚ÄîA Part is put for the Whole, implying every Kind of Divine Communication, by the prophets‚ÄîThe Mention of whom is a virtual Declaration, that the Apo≈øtle received the whole Old Te≈øtament, and was not about to advance any Doctrine in contradiction to it; hath in the≈øe la≈øt times‚ÄîIntimating that no other Revelation is to be expected; ≈øpoken‚ÄîAll Things, and in the mo≈øt perfect Manner, by his Son‚ÄîAlone. The Son ≈øpake by the Apo≈øtles. The Maje≈øty of the Son of GOD is propo≈øed, I. Ab≈øolutely, by the very Name of Son. v. 1. and by three glorious Predicates, whom he hath appointed, by whom he made, who ≈øat down; whereby he is de≈øcribed, from the Beginning to the Con≈øummation of all Things, v. 2, 3. II. Comparatively to Angels, v. 4. The Proof of this Propo≈øition immediately follows the Name of Son being proved, v. 5. His being Heir of all things, v. 6‚Äî9. his making the worlds, v. 10‚Äî 12. his ≈øitting at GOD's right hand, v. 13, &c.

V. 2. Whom he hath appointed heir of all things‚ÄîAfter the Name of Son, his Inheritance is mentioned. GOD appointed him the Heir, long before he made the Worlds, (Eph. iii. 11. Prov. viii. 22, &c.) The Son is the Fir≈øt-born; born before all Things. The Heir is a Term relating to the Creation which followed, v. 6. By whom he al≈øo made the worlds‚ÄîTherefore the Son was before all Worlds. His Glory reaches from everla≈øting to everla≈øting, though GOD ≈øpake by him to us only in the≈øe la≈øt days.

V. 3. Who ≈øat down‚ÄîThe third of the≈øe glorious Predicates, with which three other Particulars are interwoven (which are mentioned likewi≈øe, and in the ≈øame Order, Col. i. 15, 17, 20.) Who being‚ÄîThe Glory which He received in his Exaltation at the Right Hand of the Father, no Angel was capable of; but the Son alone, who likewi≈øe enjoyed it long before: the brightne≈øs of his glory‚ÄîGlory is the Nature of GOD revealed in its Brightne≈øs; the expre≈øs image, or ≈øtamp‚ÄîWhatever the Father is, is exhibited in the Son, as a Seal in the ≈øtamp on Wax; of his per≈øon, or ≈øub≈øtance‚ÄîThe Word denotes the unchangeable Perpetuity of Divine Life and Power; and ≈øu≈øtaining all things‚ÄîVi≈øible and invi≈øible, in Being, by the word of his power‚ÄîThat is, by his powerful Word; when he had by him≈øelf ‚ÄîWithout any Mo≈øaic Rites or Ceremonies, purged our ≈øins‚ÄîIn order to which it was nece≈ø≈øary he ≈øhould for a Time dive≈øt him≈øelf of his Glory. In this Chapter St. Paul de≈øcribes his Glory, chiefly as he is the Son of GOD: afterwards, c. ii. 6. &c. the Glory of the Man, Chri≈øt Je≈øus. He ≈øpeaks indeed briefly of the former, before his Humiliation, but copiou≈øly after his Exaltation: As from hence the Glory, He had from Eternity, began to be evidently ≈øeen. Both his purging our ≈øins, and ≈øitting on the right-hand of God, are largely treated of in the ≈øeven following Chapters: ≈øat down‚ÄîThe Prie≈øts ≈øtood while they mini≈øtred. Sitting therefore denotes, the Con≈øummation of his Sacrifice. This Word ≈øat down contains the Scope, the Theme, and the Sum of the Epi≈øtle.

V. 4. This Ver≈øe has two Clau≈øes, the latter of which is treated of, ver. 5. the former, ver. 13. Such Tran≈øpo≈øitions are al≈øo found in the other Epi≈øtles of St. Paul, but in none ≈øo frequently as in this. The Jewi≈øh Doctors were peculiarly fond of this Figure, and u≈øed it much in all their Writings. The Apo≈øtle therefore, becoming „Äà‚óä„Äâ Things to all Men, here follows the ≈øame Method. All the in≈øpired Writers were readier in all the Figures of Speech, than the mo≈øt experienced Orators: Being‚ÄîBy his Exaltation, after He had been lower than them, (ch. ii. 9.) ≈øo much higher than the angels‚Äî It was extremely proper to ob≈øerve this, becau≈øe the Jews gloried in their Law, as it was delivered by the Mini≈øtration of Angels. How much more may we glory in the Go≈øpel, which was given, not by the Mini≈øtry of Angels, but of the very Son of GOD? As he hath by inheritance a more excellent name‚ÄîBecau≈øe He is the Son of GOD, He inherits that Name, in Right whereof he inherits all things. His inheriting that Name is more ancient than all worlds. His inheriting all Things as ancient as all things: than they‚ÄîThis denotes an immen≈øe Pre-eminence. The Angels do not inherit all Things,
but are them≈øelves a Portion of the Son's Inheritance, whom they wor≈øhip as their LORD.

V. 5. Thou art my Son‚ÄîGOD of GOD, Light of Light; this day have I begotten thee‚ÄîI have begotten Thee from Eternity, which, by its unalterable Permanency of Duration, is one continued, un≈øucce≈ø≈øive Day. I will be to him a Father, and he ≈øhall be to me a Son‚Äî I will own my≈øelf to be his Father and Him to be my Son, by eminent Tokens of my peculiar Love. The former Clau≈øe relates to his Natural Son≈øhip, by an eternal, inconceivable Generation; the other to his Father's Acknowledgment and Treatment of him, as his incarnate Son. Indeed this Promi≈øe related immediately to Solomon, but in a far higher Sen≈øe to the Meffiah.

V. 6. And again‚ÄîThat is, in another Scripture; He‚ÄîGOD ≈øaith, when he bringeth in his fir≈øt begotten‚ÄîThis Appellation includes that of Son, together with the Rights of Primogeniture, which the Fir≈øt-begotten Son of GOD enjoys, in a Manner not communicable to any Creature: into the world‚ÄîNamely, at his Incarnation. He ≈øaith, let all the angels of God wor≈øhip him‚ÄîSo much higher was he, when in his lowe≈øt E≈øtate, than the highe≈øt Angel!

V. 7. Who ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ keth his angels‚ÄîThis implies, they are only Creatures, whereas the Son is eternal, ver. 8. and the Creator him≈øelf, ver. 10. Spirits and a flame of fire‚ÄîWhich intimates not only their Office, but al≈øo their Nature; which is excellent indeed, the Metaphor being taken, from the mo≈øt ≈øwift, ≈øubtle, and efficacious Things on Earth; but neverthele≈øs infinitely below the Maje≈øty of the Son.
V. 8. O God‚ÄîGOD, in the ≈øingular Number, is never in Scripture u≈øed ab≈øolutely of any but the ≈øupreme GOD: Thy Reign, of which the Sceptre is the En≈øign, is full of Ju≈øtice and Equity.

V. 9. Thou ha≈øt loved righteou≈øne≈øs and hated iniquity‚ÄîThou art infinitely pure and holy; therefore GOD, who, as thou art Mediator, is thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladne≈øs‚ÄîWith the Holy Gho≈øt, the Fountain of Joy; above thy fellows‚ÄîAbove all the Children of Men.
V. 10. Thou‚ÄîThe ≈øame to whom the Di≈øcour≈øe is addre≈ø≈øed in the preceding Ver≈øe.
V. 12. As a mantle‚ÄîWith all Ea≈øe. They ≈øhall be changed‚Äî Into New Heavens and a New Earth: but thou art eternally the ≈øame.

V. 14. Are they not all‚ÄîThough of various Orders; mini≈øtring ≈øpirits, ≈øend forth‚ÄîMini≈øtring before GOD, ≈øend forth to Men; to attend on them‚ÄîIn numerous Offices of Protection, Care, and Kindne≈øs; who‚ÄîHaving patiently continued in Well-doing, ≈øhall inherit overla≈øting Salvation.
Chap. ii. In this and the two following Chapters, the Apo≈øtle ≈øubjoins an Exhortation, an≈øwering each Head of the preceding Chapter.

div.head: II.
div.p:
Therefore we ought to give the more earne≈øt heed to the things which we have heard, le≈øt at any time we ≈øhould let them ≈ølip. For if the word ≈øpoken by angels was ≈øtedfa≈øt, and every tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion and di≈øobedience received a ju≈øt recompence: How ≈øhall we e≈øcape, if we neglect ≈øo great a ≈øalvation, which, having at its beginning been ≈øpoken by the Lord, was confirmed to us by them that had heard him? he that ≈øanctifieth, and all they that are ≈øanctified, are of one; for which cau≈øe he is not a≈øhamed to call them brethren, Saying,
P≈øalm xxii. 22.@ I will declare thy name to my brethren;

V. 1. Le≈øt we ≈øhould let them ≈ølip‚ÄîAs Water out of a leaky Ve≈ø≈øel. So the Greek Word properly ≈øignifies.

V. 2. In giving the Law, GOD ≈øpoke by Angels‚ÄîBut in proclaiming the Go≈øpel, by his Son; ≈øtedfa≈øt‚ÄîFirm and valid; every tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion‚ÄîCommi≈ø≈øion of Sin, every di≈øobedience‚ÄîOmi≈ø≈øion of Duty.

V. 3. So great a ≈øalvation‚ÄîA Deliverance from ≈øo great Wickedne≈øs and Mi≈øery, into ≈øo great Holine≈øs and Happine≈øs. V. 4. By ≈øigns and wonders‚ÄîWhile he lived, and various miracles

V. 5. This Ver≈øe contains a Proof of the Third; the greater the Salvation is, and the more glorious the LORD whom we de≈øpi≈øe, the greater will be our Puni≈øhment. God hath not ≈øubjected the world to come‚ÄîThat is, the Di≈øpen≈øation of the Me≈ø≈øiah; which being to ≈øucceed the Mo≈øaic was u≈øually ≈øtiled by the Jews, the world to come ‚ÄîAltho' it is ≈øtill in great Mea≈øure to come: whereof we now ≈øpeak ‚ÄîOf which I am now Speaking. V. 6. What is man‚ÄîTo the va≈øt Expan≈øe of Heaven, to the moon and ≈øtars which thou ha≈øt ordained? This P≈øalm ≈øeems to have been compo≈øed by David, in a clear Moon-≈øhiny and Star-light Night, while he was Contemplating the wonderful Fabric of Heaven; becau≈øe in his magnificent De≈øcription of its Luminaries, he takes no Notice of the Sun, the mo≈øt Glorious of them all. The Words here Cited concerning Dominion, were doubtle≈øs in ≈øome Sen≈øe applicable to Adam; altho' in their complete and highe≈øt Sen≈øe, they belong to none but the Second Adam: or the ≈øon of man that thou vi≈øite≈øt him? The Sen≈øe ri≈øes, We are mindful of him, that is Ab≈øent; but to vi≈øit denotes the Care of a pre≈øent GOD.

V. 7. Thou ha≈øt made him‚ÄîAdam: a litte lower than the angels ‚ÄîThe Hebrew is, a little lower than‚ÄîThat is, next to God. Such was Man, as he came out of the Hands of his Creator: It ≈øeems, the Highe≈øt of all created Beings. But the≈øe Words are al≈øo, in a farther Sen≈øe, as the Apo≈øtie here ≈øhews, applicable to the Son of GOD. It ≈øhould be remembered that the Apo≈øtles con≈øtantly cited the Septuagint Tran≈ølation, very frequently without any Variation. It was not their Bu≈øine≈øs, in writing to the Jews, who at that Time had it in high E≈øteem, to amend or alter this, which would of Con≈øequence have occa≈øioned Di≈øputes without End.

V. 8. Now this putting all things under him, implies that there is
nothing that is not put under him. But it is plain, this is not done now with regard to Man in general.

V. 9. It is done only with regard to Je≈øus, GOD-Man, who is now crowned with glory and honour‚ÄîAs a Reward for his having ≈øuffered Death. He was made a little lower than the angels‚ÄîWho cannot either ≈øuffer or die: that by the grace of God, he might ta≈øte death‚ÄîAn Expre≈ø≈øion denoting both the Reality of his Death, and the Shortne≈øs of its Continuance: for every man‚ÄîThat ever was or will be born into the World.

V. 10. In this Ver≈øe the Apo≈øtle expre≈ø≈øes, in his own Words, what he expre≈ø≈øed before in tho≈øe of the P≈øalmi≈øt. It became him‚Äî It was ≈øuitable to all his Attributes, both to his Ju≈øtice, Goodne≈øs, and Wi≈ødom: for whom‚ÄîAs their ultimate End: and by whom: As their Fir≈øt Cau≈øe, are all things, in bringing many adopted ≈øons to glory‚ÄîTo this very Thing, that they are Sons and are treated as ≈øuch, to perfect the cuptain‚ÄîPrince, Leader, and Author of their ≈øalvation, by his atoning Sufferings for them. To perfect or con≈øummate implies, the bringing him to a full and glorious End of all his Troubles, c. v. 9. This Con≈øummation by Sufferings intimates, 1. The Glory of Chri≈øt, to whom, being con≈øummated, all Things are made ≈øubject: 2. The preceding Sufferings. Of the≈øe he treats expre≈øly, ver. 11‚Äî18. having before ≈øpoken of his Glory, both to give an Edge to his Exhortation, and to remove the Scandal of Sufferings and Death. But unle≈øs we we were to be made the ≈øame Sacrifice, and to atone for Sin, what is ≈øaid of him in this re≈øpect, is as much out of our Sphere as his A≈øcen≈øion into Heaven. Various Afflictions indeed may be made ≈øub≈øervient to this, and ≈øo far as they are ble≈øt to the weaning us from Sin, and cau≈øing our Affections to be ≈øet on Things above, ≈øo far as they do indirectly help on our Sanctification.

V. 11. For‚ÄîThey are nearly related to each other: He that
≈øanctifieth‚ÄîChri≈øt, (c. xiii. 12.) and all they that are ≈øanctified‚Äî That are brought to GOD, that draw near, or come to him, (which are ≈øynonymous Terms) are all of one‚ÄîPartakers of one Nature, from one Parent, Adam.

V. 12. I will declare thy name to my brethren‚ÄîChri≈øt declares the Name of GOD, gracious and merciful, plenteous in Goodne≈øs and Truth, to all who believe, that they al≈øo may prai≈øe Him: In the mid≈øt of the church will I ≈øing prai≈øe unto thee‚ÄîAs the Precentor of the Choir. div.head: I.
div.p: PETER an apo≈øtle of Je≈øus Chri≈øt to the ≈øojourners ≈øcattered thro' Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, A≈øia, and Bithynia, Elect (according to the foreknowledge of God the Father) through ≈øanctification of the Spirit unto obedience, and ≈øprinkling of the blood of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. V. 1. To the ≈øojourners‚ÄîUpon Earth, the Chri≈øtians, chiefly tho≈øe of Jewi≈øh Extraction, ≈øcattered‚ÄîLong ago driven out of their own Land (tho≈øe ≈øcattered by the Per≈øecution mentioned Acts viii. 1. were ≈øcattered only thro' Judea and Samaria, though afterwards ≈øome of them travelled to Phettice, Cyprus, and Antioch) through Pontu ‚Ä¢ , Galatia, Cappadocia, A≈øia, and Bithynia‚ÄîHe names the≈øe five Provinces in the Order wherein they occurred to him, writing from the Ea≈øt. V. 2. According to the foreknowledge of GOD‚ÄîSpeaking after the Manner of Men. Hope and Love: Yea, at this very Time were rejoicing with Joy un≈øpeakable, (ver. 8.)

V. 7. That the trial of your faith‚ÄîThat is, your Faith which is tried, which is much more precious than gold (for Gold, though it hear the fire, yet will peri≈øh with the World) may be found‚ÄîThough it doth not yet appear; unto prai≈øe‚ÄîFrom GOD him≈øelf; and honour‚Äî From Men and Angels; and glory‚ÄîA≈ø≈øigned by the Great Judge.
V. 8. Having not ≈øeen‚ÄîIn the Fle≈øh.
V. 9. Receiving‚ÄîNow already, ≈øalvation‚ÄîFrom all Sin into all Holine≈øs, which is the Qualification for, the Forerunner and Pledge of eternal Salvation.

V. 10. Of which ≈øalvation‚ÄîSo far beyond all that was experienced under the Jewi≈øh Di≈øpen≈øation, the very prophets who prophe≈øied long ago of the grace of God toward you‚ÄîOf his abundant, overflowing Grace to be be≈øtowed on Believers under the Chri≈øtian Di≈øpen≈øation, enquired‚ÄîWere earne≈øtly inqui≈øitive, and ≈øearched diligently, (like Miners ≈øearching after precious Ore) after the Meaning of the Prophecies which they delivered.

V. 11. Searching what time‚ÄîWhat particular Period; and what manner of time‚ÄîBy what Marks to be di≈øtingui≈øhed; the glories that were to follow‚ÄîHis Sufferings: Namely, the Glory of his Re≈øurrection, A≈øcen≈øion, Exaltation, and the Effu≈øion of his Spirit; the Glory of the la≈øt Judgment, and of his eternal Kingdom: And al≈øo the Glories of his Grace, in the Hearts and Lives of Chri≈øtians.

V. 12. To whom‚ÄîSo ≈øearching, it was revealed, that not for them≈øelves, but for us they mini≈øtered‚ÄîThey did not ≈øo much by tho≈øe Predictions ≈øerve them≈øelves, or that Generation, as they did us, who now enjoy what they ≈øaw afar off: with the Holy Gho≈øt ≈øent down from heaven‚ÄîConfirmed by the inward, powerful Te≈øtimony of the Holy Gho≈øt, as well as the mighty Effu≈øion „Äà‚óä„Äâ his miraculous Gifts; which things angels de≈øire to look into‚ÄîA beautiful Gradation: Prophets, righteous Men, Kings, de≈øired to ≈øee and hear what Chri≈øt did and taught. What the Holy Gho≈øt taught concerning Chri≈øt, the very Angels long to know.

V. 13. Wherefore‚ÄîHaving ≈øuch Encouragement, gird up the loins of your mind‚ÄîAs Per≈øons in the ea≈øtern Countries were wont in travelling or running, to gird up their long Garments, ≈øo gather ye up all your Thoughts and Affections, and keep your Mind always
di≈øincumbered and prepared to run the Race which is ≈øet before you; Be watchful‚ÄîAs Servants that wait for their Lord: and hope to the and‚ÄîMaintain a full Expectation of all the grace‚ÄîThe Ble≈ø≈øings flowing from the free Favour of GOD, which ≈øhall be brought to you at the final revelation of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: And which are now brought to you, by the revelation of Chri≈øt in you.
V. 14. Your de≈øires‚ÄîWhich ye had while ye were ignorant of GOD.

V. 17. Who judgeth according to every man's work‚ÄîAccording to the Tenor of his Life and Conver≈øation: Pa≈øs the time of your ≈øojourning‚ÄîYour ≈øhort Abode on Earth, in‚ÄîHumble, loving fear‚ÄîThe proper Companion and Guard of Hope.
V. 18. Your vain conver≈øation‚ÄîYour fooli≈øh, ≈øinful Way of Life.
V. 19. Without blemi≈øh‚ÄîIn him≈øelf, without ≈øpot‚ÄîFrom the World.

V. 21. Who thro' him believe‚ÄîFor all our Faith and Hope proceed from the Power of his Re≈øurrection; in God‚Äîthat rai≈øed Je≈øus, and gave him glory‚ÄîAt his A≈øcen≈øion; without Chri≈øt we ≈øhould only dread GOD: Whereas through Him we believe, hope and love.

V. 22. Having purified your ≈øouls by obeying the truth thro' the Spirit ‚ÄîWho be≈øtows upon you freely, both Obedience and Purity of Heart and unfeigned love of the brethren: go on to ≈øtill higher Degre ‚Ä¢ of Love; love one another fervently‚ÄîWith the mo≈øt ≈øtrong and tender
Affection, and yet with a pure heart‚ÄîPure from any Spot of unholy De≈øire or inordinate Pa≈ø≈øion.
V. 23. Which liveth‚ÄîIs full of Divine Virtue, and abideth the ≈øame for ever.

V. 24. All fle≈øh‚ÄîEvery human Creature is tran≈øient and withering as gra≈øs; and all the glory of it‚ÄîHis Wi≈ødom, Strength, Wealth, Righteou≈øne≈øs; as the flower‚ÄîThe mo≈øt ≈øhort-lived Part of it. The gra≈øs‚ÄîThat is, Man: the flower‚ÄîThat is his Glory, is fallen off ‚ÄîAs it were, while we are ≈øpeaking.

div.head: II.
div.p:
Wherefore laying a≈øide all wickedne≈øs, and all guile, and di≈ø≈øimulation, and envies, and all evil-≈øpeakings, As new born babes de≈øire the ≈øincere milk of the word, that ye may grow thereby: Since ye have ta≈øted that the Lord is gracious: To whom coming as unto a living ≈øtone, rejected indeed by men, but cho≈øen of God and precious,
Ye al≈øo as living ≈øtones are built up, a ≈øpiritual hou≈øe, an holy prie≈øthood, to offer up ≈øpiritual ≈øacrifices, acceptable to God through Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Wherefore al≈øo it is contained in the ≈øcripture,
I≈øaiah xxviii. 16.@ Behold I lay in Sion a chief corner ≈øtone, elect, precious, and he that believeth on him ≈øhall not be confounded. Therefore to you who believe, he is precious; but as to them who believe not,
P≈øalm cxviii. 22.@ The ≈øtone which the builders rejected is become the head of the corner. And a ≈øtone of ≈øtumbling, and a rock of offence, to them who ≈øtumble, not believing the word, whereunto al≈øo they were appointed. But ye are a cho≈øen race, a royal prie≈øthood, an holy nation, a purcha≈øed people, that ye may ≈øhew forth the virtues of him who hath called you out of darkne≈øs into his marvellous light: Who in time pa≈øt were not a people, but now are
the people of God; who had not obtained mercy, but now have obtained mercy.

Beloved, I be≈øeech you as ≈øojourners and pilgrims, ab≈øtain from fle≈øhly de≈øires, which war again≈øt the ≈øoul, Having your conver≈øation hone≈øt among the Gentiles, that wherein they ≈øpeak again≈øt you as evil-doers, they may, by your good works which they ≈øhall behold, glorify God in the day of vi≈øitation. Be ≈øubject to every ordinance of man for the Lord's ≈øake, whether it be to the king as ≈øupreme, Or to governors, as ≈øent by him, for the puni≈øhment of evil-doers, and the prai≈øe of them that do well. For ≈øo is the will of God, that by well-doing ye put to filence the ignorance of fooli≈øh men: As free, yet not having your liberty for a cloak of wickedne≈øs, but as the ≈øervants of God. Honour all men, Love the brotherhood, Fear God, Honour the King. Servants be ≈øubject to your ma≈øters with all fear, not only to
the good and gentle, but al≈øo to the froward. For this is thank worthy, if a man for con≈øcience toward God endure grief, tho' he ≈øuffer wrongfully. For what glory is it, if when ye commit faults and are buffeted, ye take it patiently? But if when ye do well and yet ≈øuffer, ye take it patiently, this is acceptable with God. For even hereunto are ye called; for Chri≈øt al≈øo ≈øuffered for us, leaving you an example, that ye might follow his ≈øteps:
I≈øa. liii. 9, 7, 4, 6.@ Who did no ≈øin, neither was guile found in his mouth: Who when he was reviled, reviled not again; when he ≈øuffered he threatened not, but committed him≈øelf to him that judgeth righteou≈øly: Who him≈øelf bore our fins in his own body on the tree, that we being dead to ≈øin might live to righteou≈øne≈øs: by who≈øe ≈øtripes ye were healed. For ye were as ≈øheep going a≈øtray, but are now returned to the ≈øhepherd and bi≈øhop of your ≈øouls.
V. 1. Wherefore laying a≈øide‚ÄîAs incon≈øi≈øtent with that pure Love, all di≈ø≈øimulation‚ÄîWhich is the outward Expre≈ø≈øion of Guile in the Heart.

V. 2. De≈øire‚ÄîAlways, as earne≈øtly as new born babes do, ch. i. 3. the milk of the word‚ÄîThat Word of GOD which nouri≈øhes the Soul as Milk does the Body, and which is ≈øincere‚ÄîPure from all Guile, ≈øo that none are deceived who cleave to it, that you may grow thereby ‚ÄîIn Faith, Love, Holine≈øs, unto the full Statute of Chri≈øt.
V. 3. Since ye have ta≈øted‚ÄîSweetly and experimentally known.

V. 4. To whom coming‚ÄîBy Faith, as unto a living ≈øtone‚ÄîLiving from Eternity, alive from the Dead. There is a wonderful Beauty and Energy in the≈øe Expre≈ø≈øions, which de≈øcribe Chri≈øt as a ≈øpiritual Foundation, ≈øolid, firm, durable; and Believers as a Building erected upon it, in Preference to that Temple which the Jews accounted their highe≈øt Glory. And St. Peter ≈øpeaking of him thus, ≈øhews he did not judge him≈øelf, but Chri≈øt to be the Rock on which the Church was built: rejected indeed by men‚ÄîEven at this Day, not only by Jews, Turks, Heathens, Infidels; but by all Chri≈øtians, ≈øo called, who live in Sin, or who hope to be ≈øaved by their own Works: but cho≈øen of God‚ÄîFrom all Eternity, to be the Foundation of his Church: and precious‚ÄîIn him≈øelf, in the Sight of GOD, and in the Eyes of all Believers.

V. 5. Ye‚ÄîBelievers, as living ≈øtones‚ÄîAlive to GOD through Him, are built up‚ÄîIn Union with each other, a ≈øpiritual hou≈øe‚Äî Being ≈øpiritual your≈øelves, and an Habitation of GOD, thro' the Spirit; an holy prie≈øthood‚ÄîCon≈øecrated to GOD, and holy as He is holy: to offer up‚ÄîYour Souls and Bodies, with all your Thoughts, Words, and Actions, as ≈øpiritual ≈øacrifices to God.
V. 6. He that believeth, ≈øhall not be confounded‚ÄîIn Time or in Eternity.

V. 7. To them who believe, he is become the head of the corner‚ÄîThe chief Corner-≈øtone, on which the whole Building re≈øts. Unbelievers too will at length find him ≈øuch to their Sorrow, Matt. xxi. 44.

V. 8. Who ≈øtumble, whereunto al≈øo they were appointed‚ÄîThey who believe not, ≈øtumble, and fall, and peri≈øh for ever: GOD having appointed from all Eternity, He that believeth not, ≈øhall be damned.

V. 9. But ye‚ÄîWho believe in Chri≈øt, are‚ÄîIn an higher Sen≈øe than ever the Jews were, a cho≈øen or elect ‚Ä¢ ace, a royal prie≈øthood‚Äî Kings and Prie≈øts unto God, (Rev. i. 6.) As Princes, ye have Power with GOD, and Victory over Sin, the World, and the Devil: As Prie≈øts, ye are con≈øecrated to GOD, for offering ≈øpiritual Sacrifices. Ye Chri≈øtians are as one holy nation‚ÄîUnder Chri≈øt your King, a purcha≈øed people‚ÄîWho are his peculiar Property: that ye may ≈øhew forth‚ÄîBy your whole Behaviour, to all Mankind: the virtues‚Äî The excellent Glory, the Mercy, Wi≈ødom and Power of him‚Äî CHRIST, who hath called you out of the darkne≈øs‚ÄîOf Ignorance, Error, Sin, and Mi≈øery.

V. 10. Who in time pa≈øt were not a people‚Äî(Much le≈øs the People of GOD) but ≈øcattered Individuals of many Nations. The former Part of the Ver≈øe particularly re≈øpects the Gentiles; the latter, the Jews.

V. 11. Here begins the Exhortation drawn from the ≈øecond Motive. Sojourners: pilgrims‚ÄîThe fir≈øt Word properly means, Tho≈øe who are in a ≈øtrange Hou≈øe; the ≈øecond, tho≈øe who are in a ≈øtrange Country. You ≈øojourn in the Body; you are pilgrims in this World: Ab≈øtain from De≈øires of any Thing in this Hou≈øe, or in this Country.

V. 12. Hone≈øt‚ÄîNot barely unblameable, but virtuous in every Re≈øpect. But our Language ≈øinks under the Force, Beauty, and Copiou≈øne≈øs of the original Expre≈ø≈øions: that they by your good works which they ≈øhall behold‚ÄîSee with their own Eyes, may glorify God‚Äî By owning his Grace in you, and following your Example: in the day of vi≈øitation‚ÄîThe Time when he ≈øhall give them fre≈øh Offers of his Mercy.
V. 13. Submit your≈øelves to every ordinance of man‚ÄîTo every ≈øecular Power. In≈øtrumentally the≈øe are ordained by Men; but originally all their Power is from GOD.
V. 14. Or to ≈øubordinate governors, or Magi≈øtrates.
V. 15. The ignorance‚ÄîOf them who blame you, becau≈øe they do not know you: A ≈øtrong Motive to pity them.
V. 16. As free‚ÄîYet obeying Governors, for GOD's Sake.

V. 17. Honour all men‚ÄîAs being made in the Image of GOD, bought by his Son, and de≈øigned for his Kingdom: Honour the king ‚ÄîPay him all that Regard both in Affection and Action which the Laws of GOD and Man require.
V. 18. Servants‚ÄîLiterally, Hou≈øhold ≈øervants: with all fear of offending them or GOD: Not only to the good‚ÄîTender, kind; and gentle‚ÄîMild, ea≈øily forgiving.
V. 19. For con≈øcience toward God‚ÄîFrom a pure De≈øire of plea≈øing Him: grief‚ÄîSevere Treatment.
V. 21. Hereunto are ye‚ÄîChri≈øtians, called‚ÄîTo ≈øuffer wrongfully, leaving you an example‚ÄîWhen he went to GOD, that ye might follow his ≈øteps‚ÄîOf Innocence and Patience.

V. 22. In all the≈øe In≈øtances the Example of Chri≈øt is peculiarly adapted to the State of Servants, who ea≈øily Slide either into ≈øin or guile, reviling their Fellow-Servants, or threatening them, the natural Re≈øult of Anger without Power. He committed him≈øelf to him that judgeth righteou≈øly‚ÄîThe only ≈øolid Ground of Patience in Affliction.

V. 23. In all the≈øe In≈øtances the Example of Chri≈øt is peculiarly adapted to the State of Servants, who ea≈øily Slide either into ≈øin or guile, reviling their Fellow-Servants, or threatening them, the natural Re≈øult of Anger without Power. He committed him≈øelf to him that judgeth righteou≈øly‚ÄîThe only ≈øolid Ground of Patience in Affliction.

V. 24. Who him≈øelf bore our ≈øins‚ÄîThat is, the Puni≈øhment due to them, in his afflicted, torn, dying body on the tree‚ÄîThe Cro≈øs, whereon chiefly Slaves or Servants were wont to ≈øuffer: that we being dead to ≈øin‚ÄîWholly delivered both from the Guilt and Power of it: (Indeed without an Atonement fir≈øt made for the Guilt, we could never have been delivered from the Power) might live to righteou≈øne≈øs‚ÄîWhich is One only. The ≈øins we had committed and He bore, were manifold.
V. 25. The bi≈øhop‚ÄîThe kind Ob≈øerver, In≈øpector, or Over≈øeer of your ≈øouls.

div.head: III.
div.p:
In like manner, ye wives, be ≈øubject to your own hu≈øbands, that if any obey not the word, they al≈øo may, without the word, be won by the deportment of the wives, Beholding your cha≈øte
deportment joined with fear: Who≈øe adorning let it not be the outward adorning of curling the hair, and of wearing gold, or of putting on apparel, But the hidden man of the heart, in the incorruptible ornament of a meek and quiet ≈øpirit, which in the ≈øight of God is of great price. For thus the holy women al≈øo of old time, who tru≈øted in God, adorned them≈øelves, being ≈øubject to their own hu≈øhands, As
Gen. xviii. 12.@ Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him lord, who≈øe children ye are while ye do well, and are not afraid with any amazement. In like manner, ye hu≈øbands, dwell according to knowledge with the woman, as the weaker ve≈ø≈øel; giving them honour, as being al≈øo joint-heirs of the grace of life, that your prayers be not hindered.

Finally,
Be ye all of one mind, ≈øympathizing with each other, love as brethren, be pitiful, be courteous: Not rendering evil for evil, or railing for railing, but contrariwi≈øe ble≈ø≈øing; knowing that ye are called to this, to inherit a ble≈ø≈øing. For
P≈øalm xxxiv. 13, &c.@ let him that de≈øireth to love life and to ≈øee good days, refrain his tongue from evil, and his lips that they ≈øpeak no guile: Let him turn from evil and do good; let him ≈øeek peace and pur≈øue it. For the eyes of the Lord are over the righteous, and his ears are open to their prayer; but the face of the Lord is again≈øt them that do evil. And who is he that will harm you, if ye be followers of that which is good? But even if ye do ≈øuffer for righteou≈øne≈øs ≈øake, happy are ye; and fear ye not their fear, neither be ye troubled, But ≈øanctify the Lord God in your hearts: And be always ready to give an an≈øwer to every one
that a≈øketh you a rea≈øon of the hope that is in you, with meekne≈øs and fear: Having a good con≈øcience, that wherein they ≈øpeak again≈øt you as evil doers, they may be a≈øhamed who fal≈øely accu≈øe your good conver≈øation in Chri≈øt. For it is better, if the will of God be ≈øo, to ≈øuffer for well-doing than for evil-doing. For Chri≈øt al≈øo once ≈øuffered for ≈øins, the ju≈øt for the unju≈øt, that he might bring us to God, being put to death in the fle≈øh, but rai≈øed up to life by the Spirit, By which likewi≈øe he went and preached to the ≈øpirits in pri≈øon, Who were di≈øobedient of old, when the long-≈øuffering of God waited in the days of Noah, while the ark was preparing, wherein few, that is, eight per≈øons were carried ≈øafely through
the water: The antitype whereof, bapti≈øm, now ≈øaveth us, (not the putting away the filth of the fle≈øh, but the an≈øwer of a good con≈øcience toward God) by the re≈øurrection of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, Who being gone into heaven, is on the right-hand of God, angels, and authorities, and powers being ≈øubjected to him.
V. 1. If any‚ÄîHe ≈øpeaks tenderly: won‚ÄîGained over to Chri≈øt.
V. 2. Joined with a loving fear of di≈øpiea≈øing them.

V. 3. Three Things are here expre≈øly forbidden, curling the hair, wearing gold (by Way of Ornament) and putting on co≈øtly or gay apparel. The≈øe therefore ought never to be allowed, much le≈øs defended by Chri≈øtians.

V. 4. The hidden man of the heart‚ÄîCompleat inward Holine≈øs, which implies a meek and quiet ≈øpirit. A meek ≈øpirit gives no Trouble willingly to any: A quiet ≈øpirit bears all Wrongs without being troubled: in the ≈øight of God‚ÄîWho looks at the Heart. All Superfluity of Dre≈øs contributes more to Pride and Anger than is generally ≈øuppo≈øed. The Apo≈øtle ≈øeems to have his Eye to this by ≈øub≈øtituting meekne≈øs and quietne≈øs in the Room of the Ornaments he forbids. "I do not regard the≈øe Things;" is often ≈øaid by tho≈øe who≈øe Hearts are wrapped up in them. But offer to take them away, and you touch the very Idol of their Soul. Some indeed only dre≈øs elegantly that they may be looked on: that is, they ≈øquander away their LORD's Talent, to gain Applau≈øe: Thus making Sin to beget Sin, and then plead one in Excu≈øe of the other.

V. 5. The adorning of tho≈øe holy women, who tru≈øted in God‚Äî And therefore did not act thus from ≈øervile Fear, was, 1. Their meek Subjection to their Hu≈øbands, 2. Their quiet ≈øpirit, not afraid or amazed, and 3. Their unblameable Behaviour, doing all Things well.
V. 6. Who≈øe children ye are‚ÄîIn a ≈øpiritual as well as natural Sen≈øe, and intitled to the ≈øame Inheritance, while ye di≈øcharge your conjugal Duties, not out of Fear, but for Con≈øcience Sake.

V. 7. Dwell with the woman according to knowledge‚ÄîKnowing they are weak, and therefore to be u≈øed with all Tenderne≈øs: Yet do not de≈øpi≈øe them for this, but give them honour‚ÄîBoth in Heart, in Word, and in Action, as tho≈øe who are called to be joint-heirs of that eternal Life which ye and they hope to receive by the
free Grace of GOD: that your prayers be not hindered‚ÄîOn the one Part or the other. All Sin hinders Prayer, particularly Anger. Any Thing at which we are angry, is never more apt to come into our Mind than when we are at Prayer. And tho≈øe who do not forgive, will find no Forgivene≈øs from GOD.

V. 8. Finally‚ÄîThis Part of the Epi≈øtle reaches to ch. iv. 11. The Apo≈øtle ≈øeems to have added the re≈øt afterwards. Sympathizing ‚ÄîRejoicing and ≈øorrowing together: love‚ÄîAll Believers, as brethren, be pitiful‚ÄîToward the Afflicted; be courteous‚ÄîTo all Men. Courte≈øy is, ≈øuch a Behaviour toward Equals, and Inferiors, as ≈øhews Re≈øpect mixt with Love.
V. 9. Ye are called to inherit a ble≈ø≈øing‚ÄîTherefore their Railing cannot hurt you. And by ble≈ø≈øing them you imitate GOD who ble≈ø≈øes you.
V. 11. Let him ≈øeek‚ÄîTo live peacebly with all Men, and pur≈øue it‚ÄîEven when it ≈øeems to flee from him.
V. 12. The eyes of the Lord are over the righteous‚ÄîFor Good: Anger appears in the whole Fac ‚Ä¢ : Love chiefly in the Eyes.
V. 13. Who is he that will harm your?‚ÄîNone can.

V. 14. But if ye ≈øhould ≈øuffer‚ÄîThis is no Harm to you, but a Good: fear ye not their fear‚ÄîThe very Words of the Septuagint. I≈øa. viii. 12, 13 ‚Ä¢ Let not that Fear be in you, which the Wicked feel.

V. 15. But ≈øanctify the Lord God in your hearts‚ÄîHave an holy Fear and a full Tru≈øt in his wife Providence: the ‚Ä¢ ope‚ÄîOf eternal
Life with meekne≈øs‚ÄîFor Anger would hurt your Caufe as well as your Soul: and fear‚ÄîA filial Fear of offending GOD, and a Jealou≈øy over your≈øelves, le≈øt ye ≈øpeak ami≈øs.

V. 16. Having a good con≈øcience‚ÄîSo much the more beware of Anger, to which the very Con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of your Innocence may betray you. Join with a good Con≈øcience, Meekne≈øs and Fear, and you obtain a compleat Victory: Your good conver≈øation in Chri≈øt‚Äî That is, which flows from Faith in Him.
V. 17. It is infinitely better, if it be the will of God ye ≈øhould ≈øuffer. His permi≈ø≈øive Will appears from his Providence.

V. 18. For‚ÄîThis is undoubtedly be≈øt, whereby we are mo≈øt conformed to Chri≈øt. Now Chri≈øt ≈øuffered once‚ÄîTo ≈øuffer no more, for ≈øins‚ÄîNot his own, but ours: the ju≈øt for the unju≈øt‚ÄîThe Word ≈øignifies, not only them who have wronged their Neighbours, but tho≈øe who have tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed any of the Commands of GOD; as the preceding Word Ju≈øt, denotes a Per≈øon who has fulfilled, not barely ≈øocial Duties, but all kind of Righteou≈øne≈øs: that he might bring us to God‚ÄîNow to his gracious Favour, hereafter to his bli≈øsful Pre≈øence, by the ≈øame Steps, of Suffering and of Glory: being put to death in the fle≈øh‚ÄîAs Man, but rai≈øed to life by the Spirit‚ÄîBoth by his own Divine Power, and by the Power of the Holy Gho≈øt.

V. 19. By which Spirit he preached‚ÄîThrough the Mini≈øtry of Noah, to the ≈øpirits in pri≈øon‚ÄîThe unholy Men before the Flood; who were then re≈øerved by the Ju≈øtice of GOD as in a Pri≈øon, till he executed the Sentence upon them all: And are now al≈øo re≈øerved to the Judgment of the Great Day.
V. 20. When the long-≈øuffering of God waited‚ÄîFor an hundred and twenty Years, all the Time the ark was preparing: During which Noah warned them all, To flee from the Wrath to come.

div.head: III.
div.p:
Behold what manner of love the Father hath be≈øtowed upon us, that we ≈øhould be called the children of God; therefore the world knoweth us not, becau≈øe it knoweth not him. div.head: IV.
div.p:
Beloved, believe not every ≈øpirit, but try the ≈øpirits, whether they are of God, becau≈øe many fal≈øe prophets are gone out into the world. Hereby ye know the Spirit of God: every ≈øpirit which confe≈ø≈øeth Je≈øus Chri≈øt, who is come in the fle≈øh, is of God. And every ≈øpirit which confe≈ø≈øeth not Je≈øus Chri≈øt, who is come in the fle≈øh, is not of God: and this is that ≈øpirit of Antichri≈øt, whereof ye have heard that it cometh; and now already it is in the world. Ye are of God, beloved children, and have overcome them; becau≈øe greater is he that is in you, than he that is in the world. They are of the world: therefore ≈øpeak they of the world, and the world heareth them. We are of God; he that knoweth God, heareth us: he that is not of God, heareth not us: hereby know we the ≈øpirit of truth, and the ≈øpirit of error.
Beloved, let us love one another; for love is of God, and every one that loveth is born of God, and knoweth God. He that loveth not, knoweth not God; for God is love. Hereby was manife≈øted the love of God toward us, becau≈øe God ≈øent his only begotten Son into the world, that we might live through him. Herein is love; not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and ≈øent his Son, a propitiation for our ≈øins. Beloved, if God ≈øo loved us, we ought al≈øo to love one another. No man hath ≈øeen God at any time. If we love one another, God abideth in us, and his love is perfected in us. Hereby we know that we abide in him, and he in us, becau≈øe he hath given us of his Spirit. And we have ≈øeen and te≈øtify, that the Father ≈øent the ≈øon to be the Saviour of the world. Who≈øoever ≈øhall confe≈øs, that Je≈øus is the Son of God, God abideth in him, and he in God. And we know and believe the love that God hath to us. God is love, and he that abideth in love, abideth in God, and God in him. Hereby is
our love made perfect, that we may have boldne≈øs in the day of judgment, becau≈øe as he is, ≈øo are we in this world. There is no fear in love, but perfect love ca≈øteth out fear, becau≈øe fear hath torment. He that feareth is not made perfect in love. We love him becau≈øe he fir≈øt loved us. If any man ≈øay, I love God, and hateth his brother, he is a liar; for he that loveth not his brother, whom he hath ≈øeen, how can he love God, whom he hath not ≈øeen? And this commandment have we from him, that he who loveth God, love his brother al≈øo.

div.head: V.
div.p:
Who≈øoever believeth that Je≈øus is the Chri≈øt is born of God; and every one who loveth him that begat, loveth him al≈øo that is begotten of him. Hereby we know that we love the children of God,
when we love God, and keep his commandments, For this is the love of God, that we keep his commandments; and his commandments are not grievous. For what≈øoever is born of God overcometh the world; and this is the victory that overcometh the world,
even our faith. Who is he that overcometh the world, but he that believeth that Je≈øus is the Son of God? This is he that came by water and blood; even Je≈øus Chri≈øt; not by the water only, but by the water and the blood: and it is the Spirit who te≈øtifieth; becau≈øe the Spirit is
truth. For there are three that te≈øtify on earth, the Spirit, and the water, and the blood, and the≈øe three agree in one. And there are three that te≈øtify in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the
Holy Gho≈øt, and the≈øe three are one. If we receive the te≈øtimony of men, the te≈øtimony of God is greater; and this is the te≈øtimony of God, which he hath te≈øtified of his Son. He that believeth on the Son of God, hath the te≈øtimony in him≈øelf. He that believeth not God, hath made him a liar, becau≈øe he believeth not the te≈øtimony which he hath te≈øtified of his Son. And this is the te≈øtimony, that God hath given us eternal life, and this life is in his Son. He that hath the Son hath life; and he that hath not the Son of God hath not life.

The≈øe things have I written to you who believe on the name of the Son of God, that ye may know, that ye who believe on the name of the Son of God, have eternal life. And this is the confidence which we have in him, that if we a≈øk any thing according to his will, he heareth us. And if we know that he heareth us, what≈øoever we a≈øk we know that we have the petitions which we have a≈øked of him. If any one ≈øee his brother ≈øin a ≈øin which is not unto death, let him a≈øk, and he will give him life for them that ≈øin not unto death. There is a ≈øin unto death. I do not ≈øay that he ≈øhall pray for that. All unrighteou≈øne≈øs is ≈øin: but there is a ≈øin not unto death. We know that who≈øoever is born of God ≈øinneth not; but he that is born of God keepeth him≈øelf, and the wicked one toucheth him not. We know, that we are of God, and the whole world lieth in the wicked
one. But we know that the Son of God is come; and he hath given us an under≈øtanding that we may know the true one; and we are in the true one, even in his Son Je≈øus Chri≈øt; this is the true God and eternal life. Beloved children, keep your≈øelves from idols.

V. 1. The Scope and Sum of this whole Paragraph, appears from the Conclu≈øion of it: (ver. 13.) div.p: 'TIS ≈øcarce po≈ø≈øible for any that either love or fear GOD, not to feel their Hearts extremely affected, in ≈øeriou≈øly reading either the Beginning, or the latter Part of the Revelation. The≈øe, 'tis evident, we cannot con≈øider too much: but the intermediate Parts I did not ≈øtudy at all for many Years: As utterly de≈øpairing of under≈øtanding them, after the fruitle≈øs Attempts of ≈øo many wi≈øe and good Men; and perhaps I ≈øhould have lived and died in this Sentiment, had I not ≈øeen the Works of the great Bengelius. But the≈øe revived my Hopes of under≈øtanding even the Prophecies of this Book: At lea≈øt many of them in ≈øome good Degree; for perhaps ≈øome will not be opened but in Eternity. Let us however ble≈øs GOD for the Mea≈øure of Light we may enjoy, and improve it to his Glory.

The following Notes are mo≈øtly tho≈øe of that excellent Man; a few of which are taken from his Gnomon Novi Te≈øtamenti, but far more from his Ekklarte Offenbarung, which is a full and regular Comment on the Revelation. Every Part of this I do not undertake to defend. But none ≈øhould condemn him, without reading his Proofs at large. It did not ≈øuit my De≈øign to in≈øert the≈øe: they are above the Capacity of ordinary Readers. Nor had I Room to in≈øert the entire Tran≈ølation of a Book which contains near twelve hundred Pages.

All I can do is, partly to tran≈ølate, partly abridge the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary of his Ob≈øervations; allowing my≈øelf the Liberty to alter ≈øome of them, and to add a few Notes where he is not full. His Text, it may be ob≈øerved, I have taken almo≈øt throughout, which I apprehend
he has abundantly defended both in the Gnomon it≈øelf, and in his Apparatus and Cri≈øis in Apocalyp≈øin.

Yet I by no means pretend to under≈øtand, or explain all that is contained in this my≈øterious Book. I only offer what Help I can to the ≈øerious Enquirer, and ≈øhall rejoice if any be moved thereby, more carefully to read and more deeply to con≈øider the Words of this Prophecy. Ble≈ø≈øed is he that does this with a ≈øingle Eye. His Labour ≈øhall not be in vain.

John to the ≈øeven churches which are in A≈øia; Grace be unto you, and peace from him who is, and who was, and who cometh, and from the ≈øeven Spirits that are before his throne, And from

V. 1. The Revelation‚ÄîProperly ≈øo called; for Things covered before, are here revealed or unveiled. No Prophecy in the Old Te≈øtament has this Title: It was re≈øerved for this alone in the New. It is as it were a Manife≈øto, wherein the Heir of all Things declares, That all Power is given Him in Heaven and Earth, and that He will in the End gloriou≈øly exerci≈øe that Power, maugre all the Oppo≈øition of all his Enemies. Of Je≈øus Chri≈øt‚ÄîNot, of John the Divine, a Title added in latter Ages. Certain it is, that Appellation, the Divine, was not brought into the Church, much le≈øs was it affixed to John the Apo≈øtle, till long after the Apo≈øtolic Age. It was St. John indeed who wrote this Book; but the Author of it is Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Which God gave unto him‚ÄîAccording to his holy, glorified Humanity, as the Great Prophet of the Church. GOD gave the Revelation to Je≈øus Chri≈øt, Je≈øus Chri≈øt made it known to his Servants. To ≈øhew‚ÄîThis Word recurs, ch. xxii. 6. And in many Places the Parts of this Book refer to each other. In this Manner does it di≈øplay the manifold Wi≈ødom of GOD ≈øhining in the Oeconomy of the Church through ≈øo many Ages. His ≈øervants‚ÄîMuch is comprehended in this Appellation. 'Tis a great Thing to be a Servant of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. This Book is dedicated particularly to the Servants of Chri≈øt in the ≈øeven Churches in A≈øia: But not exclu≈øive of all his other Servants, in all Nations and Ages. It is one ≈øingle Revelation, and yet ≈øufficient for them all, from the
Time it was written to the End of the World. Serve thou the LORD Je≈øus Chri≈øt in Truth. So ≈øhalt thou learn his Secret in this Book. Yea, and thou ≈øhalt feel in thy Heart, whether this Book be divine or not. The things which mu≈øt ≈øhortly come to pa≈øs‚ÄîThe Things contained in this Prophecy did begin to be accompli≈øhed ≈øhortly after it was given; and the whole might be ≈øaid to come to pa≈øs ≈øhortly, in the ≈øame Sen≈øe as St. Peter ≈øays, The end of all things is at hand; and our LORD him≈øelf. behold I come quickly. There is in this Book a rich Trea≈øure of all the Doctrines pertaining to Faith and Holine≈øs. But the≈øe are al≈øo delivered in other Parts of Holy Writ; ≈øo that the Revelation need not to have been given for the Sake of the≈øe. The peculiar De≈øign of this is, To ≈øhew the things which mu≈øt come to pa≈øs. And this we are e≈øpecially to have before our Eyes, whenever we read or hear it.

It is ≈øaid afterward, Write what thou ≈øe ‚Ä¢ ≈øt: and again, Write what thou ha≈øt ≈øeen, and what is, and what ≈øhall be hereafter: But here where the Scope of the Book is ≈øhewn, it is only ≈øaid, the things which mu≈øt come to pa≈øs. Accordingly the ≈øhewing things to come, is the great Point in View throughout the whole. And St. John writes what he has ≈øeen, and what is, only as it has an Influence on, or gives Light to, what ≈øhall be. And be‚ÄîJe≈øus Chri≈øt, ≈øent and ≈øignified them, ≈øhewed them by Signs or Emblems (≈øo the Greek Word properly means) by his angel‚ÄîPeculiarly called in the Sequel, The angel of God, and particularly mentioned, ch. xvii. 1. xxi. 9. xxii. 6, 16. V. 2. Who hath te≈øtified‚ÄîIn the following Book, the word of God ‚ÄîGiven directly by GOD, and the te≈øtimony of Je≈øus Chri≈øt‚ÄîWhich he hath left us, as the faithful and true Witne≈øs, what≈øoever things be ≈øaw‚ÄîIn ≈øuch a Manner as was a full Confirmation of the Divine Original of this Book.

V. 3. Happy is be that readeth, and they that hear the words of this Prophecy‚ÄîSome have mi≈øerably handled this Book. Hence others are afraid to touch it. And while they de≈øire to know all Things el≈øe, reject only the Knowledge of tho≈øe which GOD hath ≈øhewn. They enquire after any thing rather than this: as if it were written. Nor are Helps wanting whereby any ≈øincere and diligent Enquirer may under≈øtand what he reads therein. The Book it≈øelf is written in the mo≈øt accurate Manner po≈ø≈øible. It di≈øtingui≈øhes the ≈øeveral Things whereof it treats by ≈øeven Epi≈øtles, ≈øeven Seals, ≈øeven Trumpets, ≈øeven Phials; each of which Sevens is divided into Four and

And much Light ari≈øes from comparing it with the ancient Prophecies, and the Predictions in the other Books of the New Te≈øtament.

In this Book our LORD has comprized what was wanting in tho≈øe Prophecies, touching the Time which followed his A≈øcen≈øion, and the End of the Jewi≈øh Polity. V. 1. Write‚ÄîSo Chri≈øt dictated to him every Word. The≈øe things ≈øaith he who holdeth the ≈øeven ≈øtars in his right-hand‚ÄîSuch is his mighty Power! Such his Favour to them and Care over them, that they may indeed ≈øhine as Stars, both by Purity of Doctrine and Holine≈øs of Life! V. 2. I know‚ÄîJe≈øus knows all the Good and all the Evil, which his Servants and his Enemies ≈øuffer and do. 1. Thy Labour:
2. Thy Patience.

4. Thou ha≈øt tried tho≈øe who ≈øay they are Apo≈øtles and are not, and ha≈øt found them Liars.
5. Thou ha≈øt Patience:
6. Thou ha≈øt borne for my Name's Sake and ha≈øt not fainted:
And thy patience‚ÄîNotwith≈øtanding which thou can≈øt not bear that incorrigibly wicked men ≈øhould remain in the Flock of Chri≈øt. And thou
ha≈øt tried tho≈øe who ≈øay they are apo≈øtles, and are not‚ÄîFor the LORD hath not ≈øent them.

V. 4. But I have again≈øt thee, that thou ha≈øt left thy fir≈øt love‚ÄîThat Love for which all that Church was ≈øo eminent, when St. Paul wrote his Epi≈øtle to them. He need not have left this. But he had not kept (as he might have done) the fir≈øt tender Love, in its Vigour and Warmth. Reader, Ha≈øt thou?

V. 5. It is not po≈ø≈øible for any to recover the fir≈øt Love, but by taking the≈øe three Steps, 1. Remember; 2. Repent; 3. Do the fir≈øt works. Remember from whence thou art fallen‚ÄîFrom what Degree of Faith, Love, Holine≈øs, though perhaps in≈øen≈øibly. And repent‚Äî Which in the very lowe≈øt Sen≈øe implies, a deep and lively Conviction of thy Fall. Of the ≈øeven Angels, Two, at Ephe≈øus and at Pergamos, were in a mixed State: Two, at
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
and at Laodicea, were greatly corrupted. All the≈øe are exhorted to repent; as are the Followers of Jezebel at Thyatira. Two, at Smyrna and Philadelphia, were in a flouri≈øhing State, and are therefore only exhorted to Stedfa≈øtne≈øs.

There can be no State, either of any Pa≈øtor, Church, or ≈øingle Per≈øon, which has not here ≈øuitable In≈øtructions. All, whether Mini≈øters or Hearers, together with their ≈øecret or open Enemies, in all Places and all Ages, may draw hence nece≈ø≈øary Self-Knowledge, Reproof, Commendation, Warning or Confirmation. Whether any be as dead as the Angel at Sardis, or as much alive as the Angel at Philadelphia: this Book is ≈øent to Him, and the Lord Je≈øus hath ≈øomething to ≈øay to him therein. For the ≈øeven Churches with their Angels repre≈øent the whole Chri≈øtian Church, di≈øper≈øed throughout the whole World, as it ≈øub≈øi≈øts not (as ≈øome have imagined) in one Age after another, but in every Age. This is a Point of deep Importance, and always nece≈ø≈øary to be remembered: That the≈øe ≈øeven Churches are, as it were, a Sample of the whole Church of Chri≈øt, as it was then, as it is now, and as it will be in all Ages. Do the fir≈øt works‚Äîoutwardly and inwardly, or thou can≈øt never regain the fir≈øt Love: But if not‚ÄîBy this Word is the Warning ≈øharpened to tho≈øe five Churches which are called to repent: (for if Ephe≈øus was threatened, how much more ≈øhall Sardis and Laodicea be afraid!) And according as they obey the Call or not, there is a Promi≈øe or a Threatning (ch. ii. 5, 16, 22. ch. iii. 3, 20.) But even in the Threatning the Promi≈øe is implied, in ca≈øe of true Repentance. I come to thee, and will remove thy candle≈øtick out of its place‚ÄîI will remove, unle≈øs thou repent, the Flock now under thy Care to another
Place, where they ≈øhall be better taken Care of. But from the flouri≈øhing State of the Church of Ephe≈øus after this, there is Rea≈øon to believe he did repent.

V. 6. But thou ha≈øt this‚ÄîDivine Grace ≈øeeks whatever may help him that is fallen to recover his Standing: that thou hate≈øt the works of the Nicolaitans‚ÄîProbably ≈øo called from Nicolas, one of the ≈øeven Deacons, (Acts vi. 5.) Their Doctrines and Lives were equally corrupt. They allowed the mo≈øt abominable Lewdne≈øs and Adulteries, as well as ≈øacrificing to Idols; all which they placed among Things indifferent, and pleaded for as Branches of Chri≈øtian Liberty.

V. 7. He that hath an ear, let him hear‚ÄîEvery Man, whoever can hear at all, ought carefully to hear this. What the ≈øpirit ≈øaith‚ÄîIn the≈øe great and precious Promi≈øes to the churches‚ÄîAnd in them to every one that overcometh: that goeth on from Faith, and by Faith to full Victory over the World, and the Fle≈øh and the Devil.

In the≈øe Seven Letters Twelve Promi≈øes are contained, which are an Extract of all the Promi≈øes of GOD. Some of them are not expre≈øsly „Äà‚óä„Äâ again in this Book, as the hidden manna, the In≈øcription o ‚Ä¢
the name of the new Jeru≈øalem, the fitting upon the throne. Some re≈øemble what is aftewards mentioned, as the hidden name, (ch. xix. 12.) the ruling the nations (ch. xix. 15.) the morning ≈øtar, (ch. xxii. 16.) And ≈øome are expre≈øsly mentioned, as the tree of life, (ch. xxii. 2.) Freedom from the ≈øecond death, (ch. ix. 6.) the Name in the book of life, (ch. xx. 12. xxi. 27.) the remaining in the temple of God, (ch. vii. 13.) the In≈øcription of the name of God and of the Lamb, (ch. xiv. 1. xiii. 4.) That Part is expre≈ø≈øed which has mo≈øt Re≈øemblance to the Virtues or Works of him that was ≈øpoken to in the Letter preceding. To eat of the tree of life‚ÄîThe fir≈øt Thing promi≈øed in the≈øe Letters, is the la≈øt and highe≈øt in the Accompli≈øhment (ch. xxii. 2, 14, 19.) V. 8. The≈øe things ≈øaith the Fir≈øt and the La≈øt, who was dead and is alive‚ÄîHow directly does this De≈øcription tend to confirm him again≈øt the Fear of Death? (ver. 10, 11.) Even with the Comfort where-with

V. 9. I know thy affliction and poverty‚ÄîA poor Prerogative in the Eyes of the World! The Angel at Philadelphia likewi≈øe had in their Sight but a little ≈øtrength.
