Who ≈øay they are Jews‚ÄîGOD's own People, and are not ‚ÄîThey are not Jews inwardly, not circumci≈øed in Heart; but a ≈øynagegue of Satan‚ÄîWho, like them, was a Liar and a Murderer, from the Beginning.

V. 10. The fir≈øt and la≈øt Words of this Ver≈øe are particularly directed to the Mini≈øter; whence we may gather, that his Suffering and the Affliction of the Church were at the ≈øame Time, and of the ≈øame Continuance. Fear none of tho≈øe things which thou art about to ≈øuffer‚ÄîProbably by Means of the fal≈øe Jews. Behold‚ÄîThis intimates the Nearne≈øs of the Affliction. Perhaps the ten days began, on the very Day that the Revelation was read at Smyrna, or at lea≈øt, very ≈øoon after. The devil‚ÄîWho ≈øets all Per≈øecutors to Work; and the≈øe more particularly: is about to ca≈øt ≈øome of you‚ÄîChri≈øtians at Smyrna; where, in the fir≈øt Ages, the Blood of many Martyrs was ≈øhed: into pri≈øon, that ye may be tried‚ÄîTo your un≈øpeakable Advantage. (1 Pet. iv. 12-14.) And ye ≈øhall have affliction‚ÄîEither in your own Per≈øons, or by ≈øympathizing with your Brethren: Ten days‚Äî(Literally taken) in the End of Domitian's Per≈øecution, which was ≈øtopt, by the Edict of the Emperor Nerva. Be thou faithful‚ÄîOur LORD does not ≈øay, till I come, (as in the other Letters) but unto death‚ÄîSignifying that the Angel of this Church ≈øhould quickly after ≈øeal his Te≈øtimony with his Blood: Fifty Years before the Martyrdom of Polycarp, for whom ≈øome have mi≈øtaken him. And I will give thee the crown of life‚ÄîThe peculiar Reward of them who are faithful unto death.
V. 11. The ≈øecond death‚ÄîThe lake of fire, The Portion of the fearful, who do not overcome (ch. xxi. 8.)
V. 12. The ≈øword‚ÄîWith which I will cut off the Impenitent. ver. 16.

V. 13. Where the throne of Satan is‚ÄîPergamos was above Mea≈øure given to Idolatry: So Satan had his Throne and full Re≈øidence there. Thou holde≈øt fa≈øt my name‚ÄîOpenly and re≈øolutely confe≈ø≈øing me before Men: in the days wherein Antipas‚ÄîMartyred under Domitian: was my faithful witne≈øs‚ÄîHappy is he, to whom Je≈øus, the faithful and true Witne≈øs giveth ≈øuch a Te≈øtimony!

V. 14. But thou ha≈øt there‚ÄîWhom thou oughte≈øt to have immediately ca≈øt out from the Flock: them that hold the doctrine of Balaam ‚ÄîDoctrine nearly re≈øembling his: who taught Balak‚ÄîAnd the re≈øt of the Moabites, to ca≈øt a ≈øtumbling-block before the ≈øons of I≈ørael‚Äî They are generally termed the children, but here the ≈øons of I≈ørael, in Oppo≈øition to the daughters of Moab, by whom Balaam inticed them to Fornication and Idolatry: To eat things ≈øacrificed to idols‚ÄîWhich in ≈øo idolatrous a City as Pergamas, was in the highe≈øt Degree hurtful to Chri≈øtianity: and to commit fornication‚ÄîWhich was con≈øtantly joined with the Idol-wor≈øhip of the Heathens.
V. 15. In like manner, thou al≈øo‚ÄîAs well as the Angel at Ephe≈øus: ha≈øt them that hold the doctrine of the Nicol√¢itans‚ÄîAnd thou ≈øuffere≈øt them to remain in the Flock.

V. 16. If not, I come to thee‚ÄîWho wilt not wholly e≈øcape, when I puni≈øh Them: and will fight with them‚ÄîNot with the Nicol√¢itans, who are mentioned only by the by; but the Followers of Balaam: with the ≈øword of my mouth‚ÄîWith my ju≈øt and fierce Di≈øplea≈øure. Balaam him≈øelf was fir≈øt with≈øtood by the Angel of the LORD with his ≈øword drawn, (Numb. xxii. 23.) and afterwards ≈ølain with the ≈øword, Numb. xxxi. 8.

V. 17. To him that overcometh‚ÄîAnd eateth not of tho≈øe Sacrifices: will I give of the hidden manna‚ÄîDe≈øcribed John vi. The new Name an≈øwers to this: It is now hid with Chri≈øt in God. The Jewi≈øh Manna was kept in the antient Ark of the Covenant. The Heavenly Arke
of the Covenant appears under the Trumpet of the Seventh Angel (ch. xi. 19.) where al≈øo the hidden manna is mentioned again. It ≈øeems properly to mean, the full, glorious, everla≈øting Fruition of GOD. And I will give him a white ≈øtone‚ÄîThe Antients, on many Occa≈øions, gave their Votes in Judgment by ≈ømall Stones; by Black they condemned; by White ones they acquitted. Sometimes al≈øo they wrote on ≈ømall, ≈ømooth Stones. Here may be an Allu≈øion to both. And a new name‚ÄîSo Jacob, after his Victory, gained the new Name of I≈ørael. Would≈øt thou know, what thy new name will be? The Way to this is plain: Overcome. Till then all thy Enquiries are vain. Thou wilt then read it on the white ≈øtone.

V. 18. And to the angel of the church at Thyatira‚ÄîWhere the Faithful were but a little Flock: The≈øe things ≈øaith the Son of God‚Äî See how great he is, who appeared like a Son of man! (ch. i. 13.) Who hath eyes as a flame of fire‚ÄîSearching the reins and the heart, ver. 23. and his feet like fine bra≈øs‚ÄîDenoting his immen≈øe Strength. Job comprizes both the≈øe, his Wi≈ødom to di≈øcern whatever is ami≈øs, and his Power to avenge it, in one Sentence, (ch. xlii. 2.) No thought is hidden from him, and he can do all things.

V. 19. I know thy love‚ÄîHow different a Character is this, from that of the Angel of the Church at Ephe≈øus? The latter could not bear the wicked, and hated the works of the Nicolaitans; but had left his fir≈øt love and fir≈øt Works. The former retained his fir≈øt Love, and had more and more Works, but did bear the wicked, did not with≈øtand them with becoming Vehemence. Mixt Characters both: Yet the latter, not the former, is reproved for his Fall, and commanded to repent. And faith, and thy ≈øervice, and patience‚ÄîLove is ≈øhewn, exerci≈øed, and improved by ≈øerving GOD and our Neighbour: So is Faith by Patience and Good Works.

V. 20. But thou ≈øuffere≈øt that woman Jezebel‚ÄîWho ought not to teach at all, (1 Tim. ii. 12.) to teach and ≈øeduce my ≈øervants‚ÄîAt Pergamos where many Followers of Balaam; at Thyatira, One grand Deceiver. Many of the antients have delivered, that this was the Wife of the Pa≈øtor him≈øelf. Jezebel of old led the People of GOD so open Idolatry. This Jezebel (fitly called by her Name, from
the Re≈øemblance between their Works) led them to partake in the Idolatry of the Heathens. This ≈øhe ≈øeams to have done by fir≈øt inticing them to Fornication, ju≈øt as Balaam did: Whereas at Pergamos they were fir≈øt inticed to Idolatry, and afterwards to Fornication.
V. 21. And I gave her time to repent‚ÄîSo great is the Power of Chri≈øt: but ≈øhe will not repent‚ÄîSo, tho' Repentance is the Gift of GOD, Man may refu≈øe it: GOD will not compel.

V. 22. I will ca≈øt her into a bed‚Äîinto great affliction‚Äîand them that commit either carnal or ≈øpiritual adultery with her, unle≈øs they repent‚ÄîShe had her Time before: of her works‚ÄîTho≈øe to which ≈øhe had inticed them, and which ≈øhe had committed with them.

It is ob≈øervable, the Angel of the Church at Thyatira, was only blamed, for ≈øuffering her. This Fault cea≈øed when GOD took Vengeance on her. Therefore he is not expre≈øsly exhorted to repent, tho' it is implied.

V. 23. And I will kill her children‚ÄîTho≈øe which ≈øhe hath borne in Adultery, and them whom ≈øhe hath ≈øeduced: with death‚ÄîThis Expre≈ø≈øion denotes Death by the Plague, or by ≈øome manife≈øt Stroke of GOD's Hand. And all the churches‚ÄîTo which thou now write≈øt, ≈øhall know, that I ≈øearch the reins‚ÄîThe De≈øires, and hearts‚ÄîThoughts.

V. 24. But I ≈øay to you who do not bold this doctrine‚ÄîOf Jezebel: Who have not known the depths of Satan‚ÄîO happy Ignorance! as they ≈øpeak‚ÄîThat were continually boa≈øting of the deep things which they taught. Our LORD owns they were deep, even deep as Hell; for they were the very Depths of Satan. Were the≈øe the ≈øame of which Martin Luther ≈øpeaks? 'Tis well if there are not ≈øome of his Countrymen, now in England, who know them too well! I will lay upon you no other burden‚ÄîThan that you have already ≈øuffered from Jezebel and her Adherents.
V. 25. What ye‚ÄîBoth the Angel and the Church have.

V. 26. My works‚ÄîTho≈øe which I have commanded; To him
will I give power over the nations‚ÄîThat is, I will give him to ≈øhare with me in that glorious Victory, which the Father hath promi≈øed me over all the Nations who as yet re≈øi≈øt me. (P≈øalm ii. 8, 9.)

V. 27. And he ≈øhall rule them‚ÄîThat is, ≈øhall ≈øhare with me when I do this: with a rod of iron‚ÄîWith irre≈øi≈øtible Power, employed on tho≈øe only, who will not otherwi≈øe ≈øubmit; who will hereby be da≈øhed in pieces‚ÄîTotally conquered.

V. 28. I will give him the morning-≈øtar‚ÄîThou, O Je≈øus, art the Morning-≈øtar. O give Thy≈øelf to me! Then will I de≈øire no Sun, only Thee, who art the Sun al≈øo. He whom this Star enlightens, has always Morning and no Evening. The Duties and Promi≈øes here an≈øwer each other: The valiant Conqueror has Power over the ≈øtubborn Nations. And he that after having conquered his Enemies, keeps the Works of Chri≈øt to the End, ≈øhall have the Morning-≈øtar ‚Äîan un≈øpeakable Brightne≈øs and peaceable Dominion in Him.

div.head: III.
div.p:
And to the angel of the church at Sardis write, The≈øe things ≈øaith he that hath the ≈øeven ≈øpirits of God, and the ≈øeven ≈øtars, I know thy works, that thou ha≈øt a name that thou live≈øt, but art dead. Be watchful, and ≈øtrengthen the things which remain, which were ready to die; for I have not found thy works compleat before my God. Remember therefore how thou ha≈øt received and heard, and hold fa≈øt, and repent. If thou watch not, I will come as a thief, and thou ≈øhalt not know at what hour I will
come up on thee, Yet thou ha≈øt a few names in Sardis, who have not defiled their garments; and they ≈øhall walk with me in white: they are worthy. He that overcometh, he ≈øhall be clothed in white raiment, and I will not blot his name out of the book of life, and I will confe≈øs his name, before my Father and before his angels. Behold I bring them of the ≈øynagogue of Satan, who ≈øay they are Jews and are not, but lie; behold, I will make them come and bow down before thy feet, and know that I have loved thee: Becau≈øe thou ha≈øt kept the word of my patience, I al≈øo will keep thee, from the hour of temptation, which ≈øhall come upon the whole world, to try them that dwell upon the earth. I come quickly. Hold fa≈øt what thou ha≈øt, that none take thy crown. He that overcometh, I will make him a pillar in the temple of my God, and he ≈øhall go out no more: and I will write upon him the ‚Ä¢ me of my God, and the name of the city of my God, the New Jeru≈øalem, which cometh down out of heaven from my God, and my new name. V. 11. Worthy art thou to receive‚ÄîThis he receives not only when ‚Ä¢ e is thus prai≈øed, but al≈øo when he de≈øtroys his Enemies and glori
‚Ä¢ es him≈øelf anew: the glory, and the honour, and the power‚ÄîAn≈øwering the thrice-holy of the living Creatures, ver. 9. div.head: V.
div.p:
And I ≈øaw in the right-hand of him that ≈øat upon the throne a book written within and without,

And none in heaven, or on earth, neither under the earth, was able to open the book, neither to look thereon. And I wept much, that none was found worthy to
open the book, neither to look thereon. And one of the elders ≈øaith to me, Weep not; behold the Lion of the tribe of Judah, the root of David, hath prevailed to open the book and the ≈øeals thereof. And I beheld in the mid≈øt of the throne and of the four living creatures, and in the mid≈øt of the elders, a Lamb ≈øtanding as if he had been ≈ølain, having ≈øeven horns and ≈øeven eyes, which are the ≈øeven Spirits of God, ≈øent forth into all the earth. And he came and took the book out of the right-hand of him
that ≈øat upon the throne. And when he took the book, the four living creatures and the four and twenty elders fell down before the Lamb, having every one an harp, and golden phials full of incen≈øe, which are the prayers of the ≈øaints. And they ≈øing a new ≈øong, ≈øaying, Worthy art thou to take the book and to open the ≈øeals thereof; for thou wa≈øt ≈ølain and ha≈øt redeemed us to God by thy blood out of every tribe, and tongue, and people, and nation, And ha≈øt made them unto our God kings and prie≈øts, and they ≈øhall reign over the earth. And I ≈øaw and heard a voice of many angels, round about the throne and
the living creatures and the elders; and the number of them was ten thou≈øand times ten thou≈øand, and thou≈øands of thou≈øands, Saying with a loud voice, Worthy is the Lamb that was ≈ølain to receive the power, and riches, and wi≈ødom, and ≈øtrength, and honour, and glory, and ble≈ø≈øing. And every creature which is in the heaven, and on the earth, and under the earth, and on the ≈øea, and all that are in them, I heard them all ≈øaying, To him that ≈øitteth on the throne, and to the Lamb, is the ble≈ø≈øing, and the honour, and the glory, and the ≈øtrength, for ever and ever. And the four living creatures ≈øaid Amen: and the elders fell down and wor≈øhipped.

Ch. v. ver. 1. And I ≈øaw‚ÄîThis is a Continuation of the ≈øame Narrative; in the right-hand‚ÄîThe Emblem of his all-ruling Power. He held it openly, in order to give it to him that was worthy. It is ≈øearce needful to ob≈øerve, that there is not in Heaven any real Book of Parchment or Paper, or that Chri≈øt does not really ≈øtand there, in the Shape of a Lion or of a Lamb. Neither is there on Earth any mon≈øtious Bea≈øt, with ≈øeven Heads and ten Horns. But as there is upon Earth ≈øomething, which, in its Kind, an≈øwers ≈øuch a Repre≈øentation, ≈øo there are in Heaven Divine Coun≈øels and Tran≈øactions
an≈øwerable to the≈øe figurative Expre≈ø≈øions. All this was repre≈øented to St. John at Patmos, in one Day, by way of Vi≈øion. But the Accompli≈øhment of it extends from that Time throughout all Ages. Writings ≈øerve to inform us of di≈øtant and of future Things. And hence Things which are yet to come, are figuratively ≈øaid, to be written in GOD's Book: So were at that Time the Contents of this weighty Prophecy. But the Book was ≈øealed. Now comes the opening and accompli≈øhing al≈øo of the great Things that are, as it were, the Letters of it. A book written within and without‚ÄîThat is, no Part of it blank, full of Matter, ≈øealed with ≈øeven ≈øeals‚ÄîAccording to the Seven Principal Parts contained in it, one on the Out≈øide of each. The u≈øual Books of the Ancients were not like ours, but were Volumes, or long Pieces of Parchment, rolled upon a long Stick, as we frequently roll Silks. Such was this repre≈øented, which was ≈øealed with ≈øeven ≈øeals. Not as if the Apo≈øtle ≈øaw all the Seals at once; for there were ≈øeven Volumes wrapt up one within another, each of which was ≈øealed: So that upon opening and unrolling the fir≈øt, the ≈øecond appeared to be ≈øealed up, till that was opened, and ≈øo on to the ≈øeventh. The Book and its Seals repre≈øent all Power in Heaven and Earth given to Chri≈øt. A Copy of this Book is contained in the following Chapters. By the trumpets (contained under the ≈øeventh ≈øeal,) the Kingdom of the World is ≈øhaken, that it may at length become the Kingdom of Chri≈øt. By the phials, (under the ≈øeventh Trumpet) the Power of the Bea≈øt, and what≈øoever is connected with it, is broken. This Sum of all we ≈øhould have continually before our Eyes: So the whole Revelation flows in its natural Order.

V. 2. And I ≈øaw a ≈øtrong angel‚ÄîThis Proclamation to every Creature, was too great for a Man to make, and yet not becoming the Lamb him≈øelf. It was therefore made by an Angel, and one of uncommon Eminence.

V. 3. And none‚ÄîNo Creature: No, not Mary her≈øelf: in heaven, or in earth, neither under the earth‚ÄîThat is, none in the Univer≈øe. For the≈øe are the three great Regions, into which the whole Creation is divided: was able to open the book‚ÄîTo declare the Coun≈øels of GOD, nor to look thereon‚ÄîSo as to under≈øtand any Part of it.

V. 4. And I wept much‚ÄîA Weeping which ≈øprung from Greatne≈øs of Mind. The Tenderne≈øs of Heart which he always had, appeared more clearly, now he was out of his own Power. The Revelation was not written without Tears; neither without Tears will it be under≈øtood. How far are they from the Temper of St. John, who enquire after any Thing rather than the Contents of this Book? Yea,
who applaud their own Clemency, if they excu≈øe tho≈øe that do enquire into them?

V. 5. And one of the elders‚ÄîProbably one of tho≈øe who ro≈øe with Chri≈øt, and afterwards a≈øcended into Heaven: Perhaps one of the Patriarchs; ≈øome think it was Jacob, from who≈øe Prophecy the Name of Lion is given him (Gen. xlix. 9.) The Lion of the tribe of Judah‚ÄîThe victorious Prince who is, like a Lion, able to tear all his Enemies in Pieces, the root of David‚ÄîAs GOD, the root and Source of David's Family (I≈øai. xi. 1.10.) hath prevailed to open the book‚ÄîHath overcome all Ob≈øtructions, and obtained the Honour to di≈øclo≈øe the Divine Coun≈øels.

V. 6. And I ≈øaw‚ÄîFir≈øt Chri≈øt in or on the mid≈øt of the throne; Secondly, the four living Creatures making the Inner Circle round him, and, thirdly, the four and twenty Elders, making a larger Circle round Him and them, ≈øtanding‚ÄîHe lieth no more; he no more falls on his Face; the Days of his Weakne≈øs and Mourning are ended. He is now in a Po≈øture of Readine≈øs to execute all his Offices of Prophet, Prie≈øt, and King: as if he had been ≈ølair‚ÄîDoubtle≈øs with the Prints of the Wounds which he once received. And becau≈øe he was ≈ølain, he is worthy to open the Book (ver. 9.) to the Joy of his own People, and the Terror of his Enemies. Having ≈øeven horns‚Äî As a King, the Emblem of perfect Strength; and ≈øeven eyes‚ÄîThe Emblem of perfect Knowledge and Wi≈ødom. By the≈øe he accompli≈øhes what is contained in the Book, namely, by his Almighty and All-wi≈øe Spirit. To the≈øe ≈øeven Horns and ≈øeven Eyes an≈øwer the ≈øeven Seals and the Sevenfold Song of Prai≈øe, ver. 12. In Zechariah likewi≈øe, ch. iii. 9. iv. 10. Mention is made of the ≈øeven eyes of the Lord, which go forth over all the earth: which‚ÄîBoth the Horns and the Eyes, are the ≈øeven ≈øpirits of God, ≈øent forth into all the earth‚Äî For the effectual working of the Spirit of GOD goes through the whole Creation: and that in the natural, as well as ≈øpiritual World. For could mere Matter act or move? Could it gravitate or attract? Ju≈øt as much as it can think or ≈øpeak.

V. 7. And he came‚ÄîHere was A≈øk of me (P≈øalm ii. 8.) fulfilled in the mo≈øt glorious Manner, and look‚ÄîIt is one State of Exaltation that reaches from our LORD's A≈øcen≈øion to his coming in Glory. Yet this State admits of various Degrees. At his A≈øcen≈øion, Angels, and principalities and powers were ≈øubjected to him. Ten Days after,
he received from the Father and ≈øent the Holy Gho≈øt. And now he took the book out of the right-hand of him that ≈øat upon the throne‚Äî Who gave it him as a Signal of his delivering to him all Power in Heaven and Earth. He received it, in Token of his being both able and willing to fulfil all that was written therein.

V. 8. And when he took the book, the four living creatures fell down‚ÄîNow is Homage done to the Lamb by every creature. The≈øe, together with the Elders, make the Beginning, and afterward (ver. 14.) the Conclu≈øion. They are together ≈øurrounded with a Multitude of Angels (ver. 11.) and together ≈øing the New Song, as they had before prai≈øed GOD together (ch. iv. 8, &c.) Having every one ‚ÄîThe Elders, not the living Creatures, an harp‚ÄîWhich was one of the chief In≈øtruments u≈øed for Thank≈øgiving in the Temple-Service: a fit Emblem of the Melody of their Hearts, and golden phials‚Äî „Äà‚óä„Äâ or Cen≈øers, full of incen≈øe, which are the prayers of the ≈øaints‚ÄîNot of the Elders them≈øelves, but of the other Saints, ≈øtill upon Earth, who≈øe Prayers were thus emblematically repre≈øented in Heaven.

V. 9. And they ≈øing a new ≈øong‚ÄîOne which neither they nor any other had ≈øung before, Thou ha≈øt redeemed us‚ÄîSo the living Creatures al≈øo were of the Number of the Redeemed: This does not ≈øo much refer to the Act of Redemption, which was long before, as to the Fruit of it; and ≈øo more directly to tho≈øe who had fini≈øhed their Cour≈øe, who were redeemed from the earth (ch. xiv. 1.) out of every tribe, and tongue, and people, and nation‚ÄîThat is, out of all Mankind.

V. 10. And ha≈øt made them‚ÄîThe Redeemed. So they ≈øpeak of them≈øelves al≈øo in the third Per≈øon, out of deep Self-aba≈øement, They ≈øhall reign over the earth‚ÄîThe new Earth: Herewith agree the golden Crowns of the Elders. The Reign of the Saints in general follows, under the Trumpet of the ≈øeventh Angel: particularly after the fir≈øt Re≈øurrection, as al≈øo in Eternity, ch. xi. 18. xv. 7. xx. 4. xxii. 5. Dan. vii. 27. P≈øal. xlix. 15.

V. 11. And I ≈øaw‚ÄîThe many Angels, and heard‚ÄîThe Voice and the Number of them, round about the elders‚ÄîSo forming the

And the number of them was‚ÄîAt lea≈øt two hundred Millions, and two Millions over. And yet the≈øe were but a Part of the holy Angels: Afterward (ch. vii. 11.) St. John heard them all.

V. 12. Worthy is the Lamb‚ÄîThe Elders ≈øaid (ver. 9.) Worthy art thou. They were more nearly allied to him than the Angels. To receive the power, &c. This ≈øevenfold Applau≈øe an≈øwers the ≈øeven Seals, of which the four former de≈øcribe all vi≈øible, the latter all invi≈øible Things, made ≈øubject to the Lamb. And every one of the≈øe ≈øeven Words bears a Re≈øemblance to the Seal which it an≈øwers.

V. 13. And every creature‚ÄîIn the whole Univer≈øe, good or bad, in the heaven, on the earth, under the earth, on the ≈øea‚ÄîWith the≈øe four Regions of the World, agrees the fourfold Word of Prai≈øe. What is in Heaven, ≈øays Ble≈ø≈øing; what is on Earth, Honour; what is under the Earth, Glory; what is on the Sea, Strength; is unto Him. This Prai≈øe from all Creatures begins before the Opening of the fir≈øt Seal; but it continues from that Time to Eternity, according to the Capacity of each. His Enemies mu≈øt acknowledge his Glory: But tho≈øe in Heaven ≈øay, Ble≈ø≈øed be GOD and the Lamb.

This Royal Manife≈øto is, as it were, a Proclamation, ≈øhewing how Chri≈øt fulfils all Things, and every knee bows to him, not only on earth, but al≈øo in heaven and under the earth. This Book exhau≈øts all Things, (1 Cor. xv. 27, 28.) and is ≈øuitable to an Heart enlarged as the Sand of the Sea. It in≈øpires the attentive and intelligent Reader with ≈øuch a Magnanimity, that he accounts nothing in this World great, no, not the whole Frame of vi≈øible Nature, compared to the immen≈øe Greatne≈øs of what he is here called to behold, yea, and in Part to inherit.

St. John has in View through the whole following Vi≈øion, what he has been now de≈øcribing, namely, the four living Creatures, the Elders, the Angels, and all Creatures, looking together at the Opening of the ≈øeven Seals.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
And I ≈øaw when the Lamb opened one of the ≈øeven ≈øeals, and I heard one of the four living creatures ≈øaying as the voice of thunder, Come and ≈øee.
And I ≈øaw, and behold a white hor≈øe, and he that ≈øat on him had a bow, and a crown was given him, and he went forth conquering and to conquer.

And when he opened the ≈øecond ≈øeal, I heard the ≈øecond living creature ≈øaying, Come. And there went forth another hor≈øe that was red; and to him that ≈øat thereon it was given to take peace from the earth, that they ≈øhould kill one another; and there was given him a great ≈øword.

And when he opened the third ≈øeal, I heard the third living creature ≈øay, Come. And I ≈øaw, and behold a black hor≈øe, and he that ≈øat on him had a pair of ≈øcales in his hand. And I heard a voice in the mid≈øt of the fourth living creatures ≈øaying, A mea≈øure of wheat for a penny, and three mea≈øures of barley for a penny; and hurt not the oil and the wine.

And when he opened the fourth ≈øeal, I heard the voice of the fourth living creature ≈øaying, Come. And I ≈øaw and behold a pale hor≈øe, and he that ≈øat on him, his name is Death, (and Hades followeth even with him) and power was given him over the fourth part of the earth, to kill with the ≈øcimetar, and with famine, and with death, and by the wild bea≈øts of the earth.

And when he opened the fifth ≈øeal, I ≈øaw under the altar the ≈øouls of them that had been ≈ølain for the word of God, and for the te≈øtimony which they held. And they cried with a loud voice, ≈øaying, How long, O Lord, thou Holy One and true, do≈øt thou not judge and avenge our blood on them that dwell upon
the earth? And there was given to them, to every one, a white robe; and it was ≈øaid to them, that they ≈øhould re≈øt yet for a time, till their fellow-≈øervants al≈øo and their brethren ≈øhould be fulfilled, who ≈øhould be killed even as they were.

And I ≈øaw when he opened the ≈øixth ≈øeal, and there was a great earthquake, and the ≈øun became black as ≈øackcloth of hair, and the moon became as blood; And the ≈øtars of heaven fell to the earth, as a fig-tree ca≈øteth its untimely figs, when it is ≈øhaken
by a mighty wind: And the heaven departed as a book that is rolled together, and every mountain and i≈øland were moved out of their places. And the kings of the earth, and the great men, and the chief captains, and the rich, and the mighty, and every ≈ølave, and free-man hid them≈øelves in the caves, and in the rocks of the mountains: And ≈øaid to the mountains and to the rocks, Fall on us, and hide us from the face of him that fitteth on the throne and from the wrath of the Lamb. For the great day of his wrath is come; and who is able to ≈øtand?

Chap. vi. The ≈øeven Seals are not di≈øtingui≈øhed from each other, by ≈øpecifying the Time of them. They ≈øwiftly follow the Letters to the ≈øeven Churches, and all begin almo≈øt at the ≈øame Time. By the four former is ≈øhewn, That all the public Occurrences of all Ages and Nations, as Empire, War, Provi≈øion, Calamities, are made ≈øubject to Chri≈øt. And In≈øtances are intimated of the Fir≈øt in the Ea≈øt, the Second in the We≈øt, the Third in the South, the Fourth in the North and the whole World.

The Contents, as of the Phials and Trumpets, ≈øo of the Seals, are ≈øhewn, by the Songs of Prai≈øe and Thank≈øgiving annexed to them. They contain therefore the power, and riches, and wi≈ødom, and ≈øtrength, and honour, and glory, and ble≈ø≈øing, which the Lamb received. The four former have a peculiar Connexion with each other; and ≈øo have the three latter Seals. The former relate to vi≈øible Things, toward the four Quarters to which the four living Creatures look.

Before we proceed, it may be ob≈øerved, 1. No Man ≈øhould con≈øtrain either him≈øelf or another, to explain every thing in this Book. It is ≈øufficient for every one to ≈øpeak, ju≈øt ≈øo far as he under≈øtands. 2. We ≈øhould remember, that altho' the ancient Prophets wrote the Occurrences of tho≈øe Kingdoms only with which I≈ørael had to do, yet the Revelation contains what relates to the whole World, through which the Chri≈øtian Church is extended. Yet, 3. We ≈øhould not pre≈øcribe to this Prophecy, as if it mu≈øt needs admit or exclude this or that hi≈øtory, according as we judge one or the other, to be of great or ≈ømall Importance. GOD ≈øeeth not as a man ≈øeeth. Therefore what we think great is often omitted, what we think little in≈øerted, in Scripture-Hi≈øtory or Prophecy. 4. We mu≈øt take care, not to overlook what is already fulfilled; and not to de≈øcribe as fulfilled what is ≈øtill to come.

We are to look in Hi≈øtory for the fulfilling of the four fir≈øt Seals, quickly after the Date of the Prophecy. In each of the≈øe appears a different Hor≈øeman. In each we are to con≈øider, fir≈øt, The Hor≈øeman him≈øelf; ≈øecondly, What he does.

The Hor≈øeman him≈øelf, by an emblematical Pro≈øopopoeia, repre≈øents a ≈øwift Power, bringing with it either, 1. A ≈ølouri≈øhing State, or, 2. Blood≈øhed, or, 3. Scarcity of Provi≈øions, or, 4. Public Calaraities. With the Quality of each of the≈øe Riders, the Colour of his Hor≈øe agrees. The fourth Hor≈øeman is expre≈øsly termed Death; the Fir≈øt, with his Bow and Crown, a Conqueror. The Second, with his great Sword, is a Warrior, or, as the Romans termed him, Mars: The Third, with the Scales, has Power over the Produce of the Land. Particular Incidents under this or that Roman Emperor, are not exten≈øive enough to an≈øwer any of the≈øe Hor≈øemen.

The Action of every Hor≈øeman intimates farther, 1. Toward the Ea≈øt, wide ≈øpread Empire and Victory upon Victory; 2. Toward the
We≈øt, much Blood≈øhed; 3. Toward the South, Scarcity of Provi≈øions; 4. Toward the North, the Plague and various Calamities.
V. 1. I heard one‚ÄîThat is, the fir≈øt, of the living creatures‚Äî Who looks forward toward the Ea≈øt.

V. 2. And I ≈øaw, and behold a white hor≈øe, and he that ≈øat on him had a bow‚ÄîThis Colour, and the Bow ≈øhooting Arrows afar off, betoken Victory, Triumph, Pro≈øperity, Enlargement of Empire, and Dominion over many People.

Another Hor≈øeman indeed, and of quite another Kind, appears on a white Hor≈øe, ch. xix. 11. But he that is ≈øpoken of under the fir≈øt Seal mu≈øt be ≈øo under≈øtood, as to bear a Proportion to the Hor≈øemen in the ≈øecond, third, and fourth Seal.

Nerva ≈øucceeded the Emperor Domitian at the very Time when the Revelation was written, in the Year of our LORD 96. He reigned ≈øearce a Year alone; and three Months before his Death, he named Trajan for his Colleague and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, and died in the Year 98. Trajan's Acce≈ø≈øion to the Empire ≈øeems to be the Dawning of the ≈øeven Seals. And a crown was given him‚ÄîThis, con≈øidering his De≈øcent, Trajan could have no Hope of attaining. But GOD gave it him by the Hand of Nerva: and then the Ea≈øt ≈øoon felt his Power. And he went forth conquering and to conquer‚ÄîThat is, from one Victory to another. In the Year 108 the already victorious Trajan went forth toward the Ea≈øt, to conquer not only Armenia, A≈ø≈øyria, and Mi≈øopotamia, but al≈øo the Countries beyond the Tigris, carrying the Bounds of the Roman Empire to a far greater Extent than ever. V. 3. And when he had opened the ≈øecond ≈øeal, I heard the ≈øecond living creature‚ÄîWho looked toward the We≈øt, ≈øaying, Come‚ÄîAt each Seal, it was nece≈ø≈øary to turn toward that Quarter of the World which it more immediately concerned.

V. 4. There went forth another hor≈øe that was red‚ÄîA Colour ≈øuitable to Blood≈øhed. And to him that ≈øat thereon it was given, to take peace from the earth‚ÄîVe≈øpa≈øian in the Year 75, had dedicated a Temple to Peace. But after a Time, we hear little more of Peace. All

To this Hor≈øeman there was given a great Sword‚ÄîAnd he had much to do with it. For as ≈øoon as Trajan a≈øcended the Throne, Peace was taken from the earth. V. 5. And when he had opened the third ≈øeal, I heard the third living creature toward the South, ≈øaying, Come‚ÄîAnd behold a black hor≈øe, a fit Emblem of Mourning and Di≈øtre≈øs; particularly of black Famine, as the ancient Poets term it. And he that ≈øat on him had a pair of ≈øcales in his hand‚ÄîWhen there is great Plenty, Men ≈øcarce think it worth their while to weigh and mea≈øure every thing, (Gen. xli. 49.) But when there is Scarcity, they are obliged to deliver them out by Mea≈øure and Weight. Ezek. iv. 16. Accordingly the≈øe Scales ≈øigni≈øy Scarcity. They ≈øerve al≈øo for a Token, That all the Fruits of the Earth, and con≈øequently the whole Heavens, with their Cour≈øes and Influences, that all the ≈øea≈øons of the Year, with what≈øoever they Produce, in Nature or States, are ≈øubject to Chri≈øt. V. 6. And I heard a voice‚ÄîIt ≈øeems from GOD him≈øelf, ≈øaying‚Äî To the Hor≈øeman, Hitherto ≈øhalt thou come, and no farther. Yet ≈øometimes what begins later than another Thing, ends ≈øooner; and what begins earlier than
another Thing, ends later. So the ≈øeventh Trumpet begins earlier than the Phials, and yet extends beyond them all.‚ÄîThe ≈øeven angels which ≈øtood before GOD‚Äîa Character of the highe≈øt Emmence, and ≈øeven trumpets were given them‚ÄîWhen Men de≈øire to make known openly a Thing of public Concern, they give a Token that may be ≈øeen or heard far and wide: and among ≈øuch none are more ancient than Trumpets, (Lev. xxv. 9. Numb. x. 2. Amos iii. 6.) The I≈øraelites in particular u≈øed them, both in the Wor≈øhip of GOD and in War, therewith openly prai≈øing the Power of GOD, before, after, and in the Battle (Jo≈øh. vi. 4. 2. Chron. xiii. 14, &c.) And the Angels here made known by the≈øe Trumpets, the wonderful Works of GOD, whereby all oppo≈øing Powers are ≈øucce≈ø≈øively ≈øhaken, till the Kingdom of the World becomes the Kingdom of GOD and his anointed.

The≈øe Trumpets reach nearly from the Time of St. John. to the End of the World: And they are di≈øtingui≈øhed by manife≈øt Tokens. The Place of the four fir≈øt is ≈øpecified, namely, Ea≈øt, We≈øt, South, and North ≈øucce≈ø≈øively: In the three la≈øt, immediately after the Time of each, the Place likewi≈øe is pointed cut.

The Seventh Angel did not begin to ≈øound, till after the going forth of the Second Wo: But the Trumpets were given to him and the other ≈øix together (as were afterward the Phials to the ≈øeven Angels) And it is accordingly ≈øaid of all the Seven together, that they prepared them≈øelves to ≈øound. The≈øe therefore were not Men, as ≈øome have thought, but Angels properly ≈øo called.

V. 3. And‚ÄîIn the 2d Ver≈øe the Trumpets were given to the ≈øeven Angels, and in the Sixth they prepared to found. But between the≈øe the Incen≈øe of this Angel and the Prayers of the Saints are mentioned: the interpo≈øing of which ≈øhews, That the Prayers of the Saints and the Trumpets of the Angels go together. And the≈øe Prayers with the Effects of them, may well be ≈øuppo≈øed to extend thro' all the Seven, Another angel‚ÄîAnother created Angel. Such are all that are here ≈øpoken of. In this Part of the Revelation, Chri≈øt is never termed an Angel, but the Lamb, came and ≈øtood at the altar‚ÄîOf burnt offerings, and there was given him a golden cen≈øer‚ÄîA Cen≈øer was a Cup on a Plate or Saucer. This was the Token and the Bu≈øine≈øs of the Office. And much incen≈øe was given‚ÄîIncen≈øe generally ≈øignifies Prayer. Here it ≈øignifies the Longing De≈øires of the Angels, that the holy Coun≈øel of GOD might be fulfilled. And there was much Incen≈øes for as the Prayers of all the Saints in Heaven and Earth are here joined together, ≈øo are the De≈øires of all the Angels, which art brought by this Angel, that he might place it‚ÄîIt is not ≈øaid, offer it: for he was di≈øcharging the Office of an Angel, not a Prie≈øt, with the prayers of all the ≈øaints‚ÄîAt the ≈øame time; but not for the Saints.
The Angels are Fellow-Servants with the Saints, not Mediators for them.
V. 4. And the ≈ømoke of the incen≈øe came up before GOD, with the prayers of the ≈øaints‚ÄîA Token that both were accepted.

V. 5. And there were thanderings, and lightnings, and voices, and an earthquake‚ÄîThe≈øe, e≈øpecially when attended with fire, are Emblems of GOD's dreadful Judgments, which are immediately to follow.
V. 6. And the ≈øeven angels prepared them≈øelves to found‚ÄîThat each, when it ≈øhould come to his Turn, might found without Delay. But while they do found, they ≈øtill ≈øtand before GOD.

V. 7. And the fir≈øt founded‚ÄîAnd every Angel continued to found, till all which his Trumpet brought was fulfilled, and till the next began. There are Intervals between the three Woes, but not between the four fir≈øt Trumpets. And there was hall and ≈øhe mingled with blood, and they were ca≈øt upon the earth‚ÄîThe Earth ≈øeems to mean A≈øia; Pale≈øtine, in particular. Quickly after the Revelation was given, the Jewi≈øh Calamities under Adrian began: yea, before the Reign of Trajan was ended: And here the Trumpets begin. Even under Trajan in the Year 114, the Jews made an In≈øurrection with a mo≈øt dreadful Fury; and in the Parts about Carene, in Egypt, and in Cyprus, de≈øtroyed four hundred and ≈øixty thou≈øand Per≈øons. But they were repre≈øt by the victorious Power of Trajan, and afterward ≈ølaughtered them≈øelves in va≈øt Multitudes. The Alarm ≈øpread it≈øelf al≈øo into Me≈øopotamia, where Lucius Quintius ≈ølew a great Number of them. They ro≈øe in Judea again in the ≈øecond Year of Adrian: but were pre≈øently quelled. Yet in 133 they broke out more violently than ever, under their fal≈øe Me≈ø≈øiah Bareachab; and the War continued all the Year 135, when almo≈øt all Judea was de≈øolated. In the Egyptian Plague al≈øo Hail and Fire were together. But here Hail is to be taker ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tively, as al≈øo Blood, for a vehement, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ hurtful Inva≈øion; and Fire betokens the Revenge of an ‚Ä¢ nraged Enemy, with the De≈øolation therefrom.
And they were ca≈øt upon the earth‚ÄîThat is, the Fire, and Hail, and Blood. But they exi≈øted before they were ca≈øt upon the earth. The Storm ≈øell, the Blood flowed, and the Flames raged round Cyrene, and in Egypt and Cyprus, before they reached Me≈øopotamia and Judea, And the third part of the earth was burnt up‚ÄîFifty well-fortified Cities, and nine hundred and eighty-five well-inhabited Towns of the Jews, were wholly de≈øtroyed in this War. Va≈øt Tracts of Land were likewi≈øe left de≈øolate and without Inhabitant, and the third part of the trees was burnt up, and all the green gra≈øs was burnt up‚Äî Some under≈øtand by the trees, Men of Eminence among the Jews ‚Ä¢
by the gra≈øs, the common People. The Romans ≈øpared many of the former. The latter were almo≈øt all de≈øtroyed.

Thus Vengeance began at the Jewi≈øh Enemies of Chri≈øt's Kingdom; though even then the Romans did not quite e≈øcape. But afterwards it came upon them more and more violently: The ≈øecond Trumpet affects the Roman Heathens in particular; the Third, the dead, unholy Chri≈øtians; the Fourth, the Empire it≈øelf.

V. 8. And the ≈øecond angel ≈øounded, and as it were a great mountain burning with fire was ca≈øt into the ≈øea‚ÄîBy the ≈øea, particularly as it is here oppo≈øed to the earth, me may under≈øtand the We≈øt or Europe; and chiefly the middle Parts of it, the va≈øt Roman Empire. A mountain here ≈øeems to ≈øignify a great Force and Multitude of People, (Jer. li. 25) So this may point at the Irruption of the barbarous Nations into the Roman Empire. The warlike Goths broke in upon it about the Year 230. And from that Time the Irruption of one Nation after another never cea≈øed, till the very Form of the Roman Empire, and all but the Name, was lo≈øt. The fire may mean, the Fire of War, and the Rage of tho≈øe Savage Nations. And the third part of the ≈øea became blood‚ÄîThis need not imply, that ju≈øt a third Part of the Romans was ≈ølain. But it is certain, an inconceivable Deal of Blood was ≈øhed in all the≈øe Inva≈øions.

V. 9. And the third part of the creatures that were in the ≈øea‚Äî That is, of all Sorts of Men, of every Station and Degree, died‚ÄîBy tho≈øe mercile≈øs Invaders. And the third part of the ≈øhips were de≈øtroyed‚ÄîIt is a frequent Thing to re≈øemble a State or Republic to a Ship wherein many People are embarked together, and ≈øhare in the ≈øame Dangers. And how many States were utterly de≈øtroyed by tho≈øe inhuman Conquerors? Much likewi≈øe of this was literally fulfilled. How often was the Sea ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ inged with Blood? How many of tho≈øe who dwelt mo≈øtly upon it were killed? And what Number of Ships de≈øtroyed?

V. 10. And the third angel ≈øounded, and there fell from heaven a great ≈øtar, and it fell on the third part of the rivers‚ÄîIt ≈øeems, Afric is meant by the rivers, (with which this burning Part of the World abounds in an e≈øpecial Manner) Egypt in particular, which the Nile overflows every Year far and wide. In the whole African Hi≈øtory, between the Irruption of the barbarous Nations into the Roman Empire, and the Ruin of the We≈øtern Empire, after the Death of Valentinian the Third, there is nothing more momentous than the Arian Calamity, which ≈øprung up in the Year 315. It is not po≈ø≈øible to tell how many Per≈øons, particularly at Alexandria, in all Egypt, and in the neighbouring Countries, were de≈øtroyed by the Rage of the Arians. Yet Afric fared better than other Parts of the Empire, with regard to the barbarous Nations, till the Governor of it, who≈øe Wife was a zealous Arian, and Aunt to Gen≈øerie, King of the Vandals, was, under that Pretence, unju≈øtly accu≈øed before the Empre≈øs Placidia. He was then prevailed upon to invite the Vandals into Afric; who under Gen≈øeric, in the Year 428, founded there a Kingdom of their own, which continued till the Year 533. Under the≈øe Vandal Kings the true Believers endured all Manner of Afflictions and Per≈øecutions. And thus Ariani≈øm was the Inlet to all Here≈øies and Calamities, and at length to Mahometani≈øm it≈øelf.

This great ≈øtar was not an Angel, (Angels are not the Agents in the two preceding or the following Trumpet) but a Teacher of the Church, one of the ≈øtars in the right-hand of Chri≈øt. Such was Arius. He ≈øell from on high, as it were from heaven, into the mo≈øt pernicious Doctrines, and made in his Fall a gazing on all Sides, being great, and now burning as a torch. He fell on the third part of the revers: his Doctrine ≈øpread far and wide, particularly in Egypt, and on the fountains of waters‚ÄîWherewith Afric abounds.

V. 11. And the name of the ≈øtar is called Wormwood‚ÄîThe unparallelled Bitterne≈øs both of Arius him≈øelf and of his Followers, ≈øhew the exact Propriety of his Title, and the third part of the waters became wormwood‚ÄîA very con≈øiderable Part of Afric was intected with the ≈øame bitter Doctrine and Spirit, and many men (tho' not a third Part of them) died‚ÄîBy the Cruelty of the Arians.

V. 12. And the fourth angel ≈øounded, and the third part of the ≈øun was ≈ømitten (or ≈øtruck)‚ÄîAfter the Emperor Theodo≈øius died, and the Empire was divided into the Ea≈øtern and the We≈øtern, the barbarous Nations poured in as a Flood. The Goths and Hunns in the Years
403 and 405 fell upon Italy it≈øelf with an impetuous Force; and the former in the Year 410 took Rome by Storm, and plundered it without Mercy. In the Year 452 Attila treated the upper Part of Italy in the ≈øame Manner. In 455 Valentinian the Third was killed, and Gen≈øeric invited from Afric. He plundered Rome for fourteen Days together. Recimer plundered it again 472. During all the≈øe Commotions, one Province was lo≈øt after another, till in the Year 476 Odoacer ≈øeized upon Rome, depo≈øed the Emperor, and put an End to the Empire it≈øelf.

An Eclip≈øe of the Sun or Moon is termed by the Hebrews, a Stroke. Now, as ≈øuch a Darkne≈øs does not come all at once, but by Degrees, ≈øo likewi≈øe did the Darkne≈øs which fell on the Roman, particularly the We≈øtern Empire: For the Stroke began long before Od ‚Ä¢ acer, namely, when the Barbarians fir≈øt conquered the Capital City, And the third part of the moon and the third part of the ≈øtars; ≈øo that the third part of them was darkened‚ÄîAs under the fir≈øt, ≈øecond, and third Trumpets, by the earth, ≈øea, and rivers, are to be under≈øtood the Men that inhabit them, ≈øo here by the ≈øun, moon, and ≈øtars, may be under≈øtood the Men that live under them, who are ≈øo overwhelmed with Calamities in tho≈øe Days of Darkne≈øs, that they can no longer enjoy the Light of Heaven; unle≈øs it may be thought to imply their being killed, ≈øo that the Sun, Moon, and Stars ≈øhine to them no longer. The very ≈øame Expre≈ø≈øion, we find in Ezekiel (ch. xxxii. 8.) I will darken all the lights of heaven over them‚ÄîAs then the fourth Seal tran≈øcends the three preceding Seals, ≈øo does the fourth Trumpet the three preceding Trumpets. For in this not the third Part of the Earth, or Sea, or Rivers only, but of all who are under the Sun are affected, and the day ≈øhone not for a third part thereof‚ÄîThat is, ≈øhone with only a third Part of its u≈øual Brightne≈øs, and the night likewi≈øe, the Moon and Stars having lo≈øt a third Part of their Lu≈øtre, either with Regard to tho≈øe who being dead, ≈øaw them no longer, or tho≈øe who ≈øaw them with no Satisfaction.

The three la≈øt Trumpets have the Time of their Continuance fixed, and between each of them there is a remarkable Pau≈øe: Whereas between the four former there is no Pau≈øe, nor is the Time of their Continuance mentioned; but all together the≈øe four ≈øeem to take up a little le≈øs than four hundred Years.

V. 13. And I ≈øaw and heard an angel flying‚ÄîBetween the Trumpets of the fourth and fifth Angel, in the mid≈øt of heaven‚ÄîThe three
Woes (as we ≈øhall ≈øee) ≈øtretch them≈øelves over the Earth from Per≈øia ea≈øtward, beyond Italy we≈øtward, all which Space had been filled with the Go≈øpel, by the Apo≈øtles. In the mid≈øt of this lies Pa ‚Ä¢ mos, where St. John ≈øaw this Angel, ≈øaying, Wo, wo, wo,‚Äî Toward the End of the Fifth Century, there were many Pre≈øages of approaching Calamities, to the inhabitants of the earth‚ÄîAll without Exception. Heavy Trials were coming on them all. Even while the Angel was proclaiming this, the Preludes of the≈øe three Woes were already in Motion. The≈øe fell more e≈øpecially on the Jews. As to the Prelude of the fir≈øt Wo in Per≈øia, I ‚Ä¢ degard II. in 454, was re≈øolved to aboli≈øh the Sabbath, till he was by Rabbi Mar diverted from his Purpo≈øe. Likewi≈øe in the Year 474 Phiruz afflicted the Jews much, and compelled many of them to apo≈øtatize. A Prelude of the Second Wo was the Ri≈øe of the Saracens, who in 510 fell into Arabia, and Pale≈øtine. To prepare for the third Wo, Innocent I. and his Succe≈ø≈øors, not only endeavoured to enlarge their Epi≈øcopal Juri≈ødiction beyond all Bounds, but al≈øo their worldly Power, by taking every Opportunity of in ‚Ä¢ roaching upon the Empire, which as yet ≈øtood in the Way of their unlimited Monarchy.

div.head: IX.
div.p:
And the fifth angel ≈øounded, and I ≈øaw a ≈øtar falling from heaven to the earth, and to him was given the key of the bottomle≈øs pit. And he opened the bottomle≈øs pit, and there a≈øcended a ≈ømoke out of the pit, as the ≈ømoke of a great furnace, and the ≈øun and the air were darkened by the ≈ømoke of the pit. And out of the ≈ømoke there came forth locu≈øts upon the earth, and power was given them, as the ≈øcorpions of
the earth have power: And it was commanded them, not to hurt the gra≈øs of the earth, neither any green thing, neither any tree, but only the men who have not the ≈øeal of God on their foreheads. And it was given them, not to kill them, but that they ≈øhould be tormented five months; and the torment of them is as the torment of a ≈øcorpion, when he ≈øtingeth a man. And in tho≈øe days the men ≈øhall ≈øeek death, but not find it; and ≈øhall de≈øire to die, but death will flee from them. And the appearances of the locu≈øts are like hor≈øes made ready for battle; and on their heads are as it were crowns like gold, and their faces are as the faces of men. And they had hair as the hair of women, and their teeth were
as the teeth of lions. And they had brea≈øt-plates, as it were brea≈øt-plates of iron, and the noi≈øe of their wings was as the noi≈øe of chariots of many hor≈øes running to battle. And they have tails like ≈øcorpions, and ≈øtings were in their tails; their power is to hurt men five months. And they have over them a king, the angel of the bottomle≈øs pit: his name in the Hebrew is Abaddon, but in the Greek he hath the name Apollyon. One wo is pa≈øt: behold there come yet two woes after the≈øe things.

And the ≈øixth angel ≈øounded, and I heard a voice from the four corners of the golden altar which is before
God, Saying to the ≈øixth angel, who had the trumpet, Loo≈øe the four angels who are bound in the great river Euphrates. And the four angels were loo≈øed, who were prepared for the hour, and day, and month, and year, to kill the third part of men. And the number of the army of hor≈øemen was two
hundred millions: I heard their number. And thus I ≈øaw the hor≈øes in the vi≈øion and them that ≈øat on them, having brea≈øt-plates of fire, and hyacinth, and brim≈øtone: and the heads of the hor≈øes are as the heads of lions, and out of their mouths goeth fire and ≈ømoke, and brim≈øtone. By the≈øe three plagues were the third part of men killed, by the fire, and the ≈ømoke, and the brim≈øtone which went out of their mouths. For the power of the hor≈øes is in their mouths and in their tails; for their tails are like ≈øerpents, having heads, and with them they do hurt. And the re≈øt of the men, who were not killed by the≈øe plagues, yet repented not of the works of their hands, that they ≈øhould not wor≈øhip devils and idols of gold, and ≈øilver, and bra≈øs, and ≈øtone, and wood, which can neither ≈øee, nor hear,
nor walk: Neither repented of their murders, nor of their ≈øorceries, nor of their fornications, nor of their thefts.

V. 1. And the fifth angel ≈øounded, and I ≈øaw a ≈øtar‚ÄîFar different from that mentioned, ch. viii. 11. This Star belongs to the invi≈øible World. The Third Wo is occa≈øioned by the Dragon ca≈øt out of Heaven: the Second takes Place at the loo≈øing of the four Angels who were bound in the Euphrates. The fir≈øt is here brought by the Angel of the Aby≈øs, which is opened by this Star, or Holy Angel, falling to the earth‚ÄîComing ≈øwiftly and with great Force, and to him was given‚ÄîWhen he was come, the key of the bottomle≈øs pit‚ÄîA deep and hideous Pri≈øon, but different from the lake of Fire.

V. 2. And there aro≈øe a ≈ømoke out of the pit‚ÄîThe Locu≈øts, who afterwards ri≈øe out of it, ≈øeem to be (as we ≈øhall afterwards ≈øee) the Per≈øians: Agreeable to which this Smoke is their dete≈øtable Idolatrous Doctrine, and fal≈øe Zeal for it, which now broke out in an uncommon Paroxy≈øm, as the ≈ømoke of a great furnace‚ÄîWhere the Clouds of it ri≈øe thicker and thicker, ≈øpread far and wide, and pre≈øs one upon another, ≈øo that the Darkne≈øs increa≈øes continually. And the ≈øun and the air were darkened‚ÄîA figurative Expre≈ø≈øion denoting heavy Affliction. This Smoke occa≈øioned more and more ≈øuch Darkne≈øs over the Jews in Per≈øia.

V. 3. And out of the ≈ømoke‚ÄîNot out of the bottomle≈øs Pit, but from the Smoke which i≈ø≈øued thence, there went forth locu≈øts‚ÄîA
known Emblem of a numerous, ho≈øtile, hurtful People. Such were the Per≈øians, from whom the Jews in the Sixth Century ≈øuffered beyond Expre≈ø≈øion. In the Year 540, their Academies were ≈øtopped, nor were they permitted to have a Pre≈øident for near fifty Years. In 589 this Affliction ended; but it began long before 540. The Prelude of it was about the Year 455 and 474. The main Storm came on in the Reign of Cabades, and la≈øted from 483 to 532. Toward the beginning of the Sixth Century, Mar Rab I≈øaac, Pre≈øident of the Academy was put to Death. Hereon followed an In≈øurrection of the Jews, which la≈øted ≈øeven Years before they were conquered by the Per≈øians. Some of them were then put to Death, but not many; the re≈øt were clo≈øely impri≈øoned. And from this Time the Nation of the Jews were hated and per≈øecuted by the Per≈øians, till they had well high rooted them out, The ≈øcorpions of the earth‚ÄîThe mo≈øt hurtful Kind. The Scorpions of the Air have Wings.

V. 4. And it was commanded them‚ÄîBy the ≈øecret Power of GOD, not to hurt the gra≈øs, neither any green thing, nor any tree‚ÄîNeither tho≈øe of low, middling, or high Degree, but only ≈øuch of them as were not ≈øealed‚ÄîPrincipally, the unbelieving I≈øraelites. But many who were called Chri≈øtians ≈øuffered with them.
V. 5. Not to kill them‚ÄîVery few of them were killed; in general, they were impri≈øoned and variou≈øly tormented.
V. 6. The men‚ÄîThat is, the Men who are ≈øo tormented.

V. 7. And the appearances‚ÄîThis De≈øcription ≈øuits a People neither thoroughly civilized, nor intirely ≈øavage. And ≈øuch were the Per≈øians of that Age, of the locu≈øts are like „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚ÄîWith their Riders. The Per≈øians excelled in Hor≈øeman≈øhip, and on their heads are as it were „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚ÄîTurbands, and their faces are as the faces of men‚Äî Friendly and agreeable.
V. 8. And they had ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ as the hair of women‚ÄîAll the Per≈øians of old gloried in long Hair, and their teeth were as the teeth of lions‚Äî Breaking and ‚Ä¢ earing all Things in Pieces.
V. 9. And the noi≈øe of their wings was as the noi≈øe of chariots of many hor≈øes‚ÄîWith their War-chariots drawn by many Hor≈øes, they, as it were, flew to and fro.

V. 10. And they have tails like ≈øcorpions‚ÄîThat is, each Tail is like a Scorpion, not like the Tail of a Scorpion, to hurt the un≈øealed men five months‚ÄîFive Prophetic Months, that is, ≈øeventy-nine common Years. So long did the≈øe Calamities la≈øt.

V. 11. And they have over them a king‚ÄîOne by whom they are peculiarly directed and governed. His name is Abaddon‚ÄîBoth this and Apollyon ≈øignify a De≈øtroyer. By this he is di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Dragon, who≈øe proper Name is Satan.

V. 12. One wo is pa≈øt: behold there come yet two woes after the≈øe things‚ÄîThe Per≈øian Power, under which was the fir≈øt Wo, was now broken by the Saracens; from this Time the fir≈øt Pau≈øe made a wide Way for the two ≈øucceeding Woes. In 589, when the fir≈øt Wo ended, Mahomet was twenty Years old, and the Contentions of the Chri≈øtians with each other were exceeding great. In 591 Cho≈øroes II. reigned in Per≈øia, who after the Death of the Emperor made dreadful Di≈øturbances in the Ea≈øt. Hence Mahomet found an open Door for his new Religion and Empire. And when the U≈øurper, Phocas, had in the Year 606, not only declared the Bi≈øhop of Rome, Boniface III. Univer≈øal Bi≈øhop, but al≈øo the Church of Rom ‚Ä¢ , the Head of all Churches; this was a ≈øure Step to advance the Papacy to its utmo≈øt Height. Thus, after the pa≈ø≈øing away of the fir≈øt Wo, the ≈øecond, yea, and the third quickly followed: As indeed they were both on the Way together with it, before the fir≈øt effectually began.

V. 13. And the ≈øixth angel ≈øounded‚ÄîUnder this Angel goes forth the ≈øecond Wo, and I heard a voice from the four corners of be golden altar‚Äî ‚Ä¢ his golden Altar is the heavenly Pattern of the Levitical Altar of Incen≈øe. This Voice ≈øignified, That the Execution of the Wrath of GOD (me ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oned ver. 20, 21.) ≈øhould, at no Interce≈ø≈øion, be delayed any longer.
V. 14. Loo≈øe the four angels‚ÄîTo go every Way, to the four Quarters: The≈øe were evil Angels, or they would not have been bound. Why, or how long they were bound, we know not.

V. 15. And the four angels were loo≈øed, who were prepared‚ÄîBy loo≈øing them, as well as by their Strength and Rage, to kill the third part of men‚ÄîThat is, an immen≈øe Number of them, for the hour, and day, and month, and year‚ÄîAll this agrees with the Slaughter which the Saracens made, for a long Time after Mahomet's Death. And with the Number of Angels let loo≈øe agrees the Number of their fir≈øt and mo≈øt eminent Caliphs. The≈øe were Ali, Abubeker, Omar, and O≈øman.
